The modification of catalysts and optimization of reaction conditions are emphasized. The interactions between metal ions and the zeolite support, as well as the reaction mechanisms of the formation of aromatics and carbonaceous deposits, are discussed. The channel structure and acidity of the HZSM-5 zeolite, as well as the valence and location of Mo species, are crucial factors for the catalytic performance. The loading of certain metals can enhance the reactivity and/or stability of the catalysts, while the addition of others has the opposite influence. The preparation method, the consequence of impregnation of the metal components, and the calcined temperature can also affect the performance. Various pre-treatments and different reaction conditions exert great influences on the catalytic performance. The interaction between the Mo species and HZSM-5 is significant for understanding the reaction. The introduction of Mo species and/or the addition of the second metal component changes the acid sites of the zeolite. The mode of methane activation is a focus of debate, with various active sites and reaction mechanisms proposed. The heavy carbonaceous deposit formed during the reaction is a major obstacle for understanding and process development. The real status of the Mo species during the reaction and its role in the reaction pathway are significant for methane chemistry and the development of the theory of methane activation.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件，包括支撑的钒氧化物和金属交换沸石，对烷烃转化的机制和效率有重大影响。催化剂的改性和反应条件的优化被强调。金属离子和沸石载体之间的相互作用，以及芳烃和碳沉积物形成反应机制的讨论。H-ZSM-5沸石的通道结构和酸性，以及Mo物种的价态和位置，是催化性能的关键因素。某些金属的负载可以增强催化剂的反应性和/或稳定性，而其他金属的添加则有相反的影响。制备方法、金属组分浸渍的后果和煅烧温度也会影响性能。各种预处理和不同的反应条件对催化性能有重大影响。Mo物种和H-ZSM-5之间的相互作用对于理解反应具有重要意义。Mo物种的引入和/或第二金属组分的添加改变了沸石的酸性位点。甲烷活化模式是争论的焦点，提出了各种活性位点和反应机制。在反应过程中形成的大量碳沉积物是理解和工艺开发的主要障碍。Mo物种在反应过程中的真实状态及其在Mo/HZSM-5催化剂上甲烷脱氢芳构化反应路径中的作用，对甲烷化学和甲烷活化理论的发展具有普遍意义。", "Doi": "10.1016/s0926-860x(99)00210-0"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Supported vanadium oxides are particularly noteworthy because the active sites possibly involve isolated VO species (in contrast to the other systems based on MoOx or WOx).\"\n          [2] \"Such processes are particularly important for alkenes having allylic CH bonds, e.g. propene and higher alkenes, which are more readily activated.\"\n          [3] \"Small clusters and particularly isolated sites on fully covered oxide surfaces have been proposed to be essential to achieve high selectivities.\"\n          [4] \"It is therefore not surprising that the support is an important component in the catalyst formulation, as it can more or less stabilize isolated centers, small clusters vs larger V2O5 crystallites.\"\n          [5] \"Overall, silica can be regarded as the optimal support in terms of selectivity.\"\n          [6] \"Another important fact is that the optimal temperature window for this process is quite narrow, and around 500 C, lower temperatures favor combustion while unselective gas phase reactions start to be competitive at higher temperatures (>550 C).\"\n          [7] \"ODH on supported VOx also follows the typical Marsvan Krevelen mechanism, i.e. oxidation of the alkane with a concomitant reduction of metal oxo surface species followed by a reoxidation of the active sites by molecular oxygen and desorption of water.\"\n          [8] \"The terminal oxo species of VV surface species are the most reactive O sites according to DFT calculations on a model for isolated silica supported vanadyl species.\"\n          [9] \"Similar results were obtained by periodic calculations on V2O5.\"\n          [10] \"The most favored CH bond activation step corresponds to a H-abstraction, which yields a radical intermediate and a reduced VIVOH species.\"\n          [11] \"Calculations also suggest that the formation of propene in the propane dehydrogenation is most favored via subsequent H-abstraction of the propyl radical on an adjacent isolated VO species.\"\n          [12] \"Metal exchange zeolites (M-zeolites) have concentrated a large research effort, because of their ability to transform alkanes into alkenes and aromatics.\"\n          [13] \"They can also be used to catalyze the alkylation of aromatics with methane, the coaromatization of methane and alkanes, and the direct aromatization of methane.\"\n          [14] \"While all these transformations are still subject to many mechanistic debates and detailed investigations, Malkyl species are probably key intermediates.\"\n          [15] \"These M-zeolites can be of various structures (typically identified with three letter codes: MFI, MOR, ZSM-5...) and compositions, and can include a wide range of metals M, ranging from main group (Al, Ga) to transition-metal elements (Cu, Fe, Mn, Mo, Pt, W, Zn, ...).\"\n          [16] \"A vast research effort has focused on Ga- and Zn-zeolites because of their industrial relevance and their unprecedented reactivity, and these systems will be discussed hereafter in more detail.\"\n          [17] \"Conversion of alkanes into aromatics takes place via successive dehydrogenation, oligomerization, and cyclization steps.\"\n          [18] \"Ga-zeolites act as a multifunctional catalyst, and one of the key steps, the formation of alkenes from alkanes, takes place at Ga sites and involves a CH bond activation and formation of a Gaalkyl intermediate.\"\n          [19] \"Ga-zeolites are also known to activate H2 and alkanes and to catalyze H/D exchange reactions.\"\n          [20] \"These species correspond to highly Lewis acidic centers, which can readily polarize and activate the CH bond of alkanes as well as H2 to generate GaR (or GaH) and OH surface species.\"\n          [21] \"Zn-zeolites display a very similar reactivity pattern: H2 and alkane activation, H/D exchange, formation of aromatics from alkanes, and the coaromatization of methane and alkane.\"\n          [22] \"Alkane activation (including methane) also occurs via CH bond activation and formation of metalalkyl intermediates, which have been experimentally observed on different Zn-zeolites.\"\n          [23] \"M-exchange zeolites and particularly those containing Mo or even Zn also catalyze the direct conversion of methane into benzene and H2 with a high selectivity (>90%).\"\n          [24] \"While the structure and the nature of the active sites are still a matter of debate, it is accepted that methane is first converted into ethylene, which is then converted into benzene through acid catalysis.\"\n          [25] \"Several mechanisms have been proposed for the first step involving the formation of ethylene, and they involve the following: (1) carbocations, (2) radicals, or (3) organometallic intermediates, and more specifically alkylidenes, alkylidynes, or carbides.\"\n          [26] \"It is therefore possible that CH bond activation on MoCx species leads to the growth of an alkyl chain and the formation of alkenes, similarly to what is observed in the nonoxidative coupling of methane on silica supported tantalum hydrides.\"\n          [27] \"Under oxidizing conditions, metal-exchange zeolites, and, more specifically, those containing MoOx and WOx, catalyze the direct oxidation of methane into methanol/formaldehyde and related oxidation processes.\"\n          [28] \"Fe-zeolites are also noteworthy: they catalyze the direct and selective oxidation of benzene into phenol by N2O.\"\n          [29] \"While this reaction corresponds to the selective functionalization of an aromatic CH bond, several mechanisms are possible, such as the direct insertion of O in the CH bond of benzene or the epoxidation followed by an acid catalyzed rearrangement of the unstable epoxide into phenol.\"", "English": "Supported vanadium oxides are particularly noteworthy for their active sites involving isolated VO species, which are crucial for the selective activation of alkenes with allylic CH bonds, such as propene. Small clusters and isolated sites on fully covered oxide surfaces are essential for high selectivities, with silica being the optimal support. The optimal temperature window for oxidative dehydrogenation is narrow, around 500 C, to avoid combustion at lower temperatures and unselective gas phase reactions at higher temperatures. The process follows the Marsvan Krevelen mechanism, with the terminal oxo species of VV surface species being the most reactive. DFT calculations support these findings, indicating that H-abstraction is the most favored CH bond activation step, leading to the formation of propene via subsequent H-abstraction on adjacent isolated VO species.\n          Metal-exchanged zeolites (M-zeolites) have been the focus of extensive research due to their ability to transform alkanes into alkenes and aromatics, catalyze alkylation reactions, and directly aromatize methane. The transformations involve complex mechanisms, with metalalkyl species as key intermediates. M-zeolites can have various structures and compositions, including a wide range of metals from main group to transition metals. Ga- and Zn-zeolites are of particular interest due to their industrial relevance and reactivity. The conversion of alkanes into aromatics occurs through dehydrogenation, oligomerization, and cyclization steps, with Ga-zeolites acting as multifunctional catalysts. These zeolites can activate H2 and alkanes, catalyze H/D exchange reactions, and form metalalkyl intermediates. Zn-zeolites display similar reactivity patterns, including the coaromatization of methane and alkanes. M-exchange zeolites, especially those containing Mo or Zn, can directly convert methane into benzene and H2 with high selectivity. The mechanism for the conversion of methane into ethylene is still debated, involving carbocations, radicals, or organometallic intermediates. Under oxidizing conditions, metal-exchanged zeolites containing MoOx and WOx catalyze the direct oxidation of methane into methanol/formaldehyde. Fe-zeolites are noteworthy for their selective oxidation of benzene into phenol by N2O, involving the functionalization of an aromatic CH bond.", "Chinese": "支撑的钒氧化物因其活性位点可能涉及孤立的VO物种而特别引人注目，这对于选择性激活具有烯丙基CH键的烯烃（如丙烯）至关重要。小簇和孤立位点在完全覆盖的氧化物表面上对于实现高选择性至关重要，二氧化硅是最佳的支撑体。氧化脱氢的最佳温度窗口很窄，大约在500°C，较低的温度有利于燃烧，而较高的温度（>550°C）则开始出现非选择性的气相反应。该过程遵循Marsvan Krevelen机制，VV表面物种的终端氧物种是最具反应性的O位点。DFT计算支持这些发现，表明H-抽象是最受青睐的CH键活化步骤，通过在相邻的孤立VO物种上进行后续H-抽象，形成丙烯。\n          金属交换沸石（M-沸石）因其能够将烷烃转化为烯烃和芳烃而成为大量研究的焦点，它们还可以催化烷烃与甲烷的烷基化反应，以及直接芳构化甲烷。尽管所有这些转化仍然存在许多机理争议和详细研究，但金属烷基物种可能是关键中间体。这些M-沸石可以具有各种结构（通常用三个字母代码标识：MFI，MOR，ZSM-5...）和组成，可以包括从主族（Al，Ga）到过渡金属元素（Cu，Fe，Mn，Mo，Pt，W，Zn，...）的广泛金属M。大量的研究集中在Ga和Zn沸石上，因为它们的工业相关性和前所未有的反应性。烷烃转化为芳烃通过连续的脱氢、寡聚和环化步骤发生，Ga沸石作为多功能催化剂发挥作用。这些沸石可以激活H2和烷烃，催化H/D交换反应，并形成金属烷基中间体。Zn沸石显示出非常相似的反应模式，包括甲烷和烷烃的共芳构化。M交换沸石，特别是那些含有Mo或Zn的沸石，可以以高选择性（>90％）直接将甲烷转化为苯和H2。甲烷转化为乙烯的机制仍在争论中，涉及碳正离子、自由基或有机金属中间体。在氧化条件下，含有MoOx和WOx的金属交换沸石催化甲烷直接氧化为甲醇/甲醛和相关氧化过程。Fe沸石因其通过N2O选择性氧化苯为酚而值得注意，涉及芳烃CH键的功能化。", "Doi": "10.1021/cr900122p_2"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"γ -Al2O3-supported vanadium oxide catalysts (06.3 wt% V atoms) were prepared, characterized, and tested for the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of both ethane and n-butane.\"\n          [2] \"The vana- dium loading strongly influences the catalytic behavior of γ -Al2O3- supported vanadium oxide catalysts during the ODH of n-butane and ethane.\"\n          [3] \"While the catalytic activity in the ODH reactions in- creaseswiththevanadiumloading,theselectivitytothecorrespond- ing olefins shows a maximum for catalysts with 34 wt% V atoms.\"\n          [4] \"In addition, the selectivity to oxydehydrogenation products during the ODH of butane was lower than the selectivity to ethene during the ODH of ethane.\"\n          [5] \"Associated VO4 tetrahedra were observed by 51V-NMR on catalysts with V loading lower than 5 wt%, while VO6 octahedra were predominant on catalysts with higher V loading.\"\n          [6] \"Although catalysts with octahedral V5+ species show higher catalytic activity, higher selectivity to oxydehydrogenation reactions was achieved on catalysts in which mainly tetrahedral V5+ species were observed.\"\n          [7] \"The number and nature of the acid sites also change with the vanadium loading. Thus, Lewis acid sites were ob- served mainly on catalysts with low V loading, while both Lewis and Brnsted acid sites were observed on catalysts with high V loading.\"\n          [8] \"Vanadia catalysts supported on Al2O3 have been char- acterized by a variety of physicochemical methods.\"\n          [9] \"The data obtained from Raman (1216), 51V NMR (1517), ESR (1820), XPS (14, 21), UVVis reflectance (19), EXAFSXANES (22, 23), temperature-programmed re- duction (12, 14, 23, 24), and infrared and microcalorimetric studies of adsorbed probe molecules (2527) indicate that the type of vanadium species depends on the vanadium con- tent.\"\n          [10] \"If a vanadium oxide monolayer completely covering thesurfaceofthesupportshouldneed4.98 × 1014molecules V2O5 cm2, the appearance of V2O5 crystallites on Al2O3 occurs at a vanadium loading of about 60% of the theoret- ical monolayer (14).\"\n          [11] \"At lower vanadium loadings, isolated and/or associated tetrahedral and/or octahedral V5+ species have been observed.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, such as supported vanadium oxides, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations in oxidative dehydrogenation processes. The vanadium loading on γ -Al2O3-supported vanadium oxide catalysts strongly affects the catalytic behavior for the oxidative dehydrogenation of n-butane and ethane. The catalytic activity increases with the vanadium loading, but the selectivity to corresponding olefins shows a maximum for catalysts with 3-4 wt% V atoms. The selectivity to oxydehydrogenation products during the oxidative dehydrogenation of butane is lower than the selectivity to ethene during the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane. The type of vanadium species, such as VO4 tetrahedra or VO6 octahedra, depends on the vanadium content, with tetrahedral V5+ species observed on catalysts with lower V loading and octahedral V5+ species predominant on catalysts with higher V loading. Catalysts with octahedral V5+ species show higher catalytic activity, but higher selectivity to oxydehydrogenation reactions is achieved on catalysts with mainly tetrahedral V5+ species. The number and nature of acid sites, such as Lewis and Brnsted acid sites, also change with the vanadium loading. The type of vanadium species and the nature of acid sites contribute to the industrial significance of these catalysts by affecting the selectivity and activity in alkane transformations.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件，如支撑的钒氧化物，在氧化脱氢过程中对烷烃转化的机制和效率有重大影响。γ -Al2O3支撑的钒氧化物催化剂上的钒负载量对n-丁烷和乙烷的氧化脱氢的催化行为有重大影响。催化活性随钒负载量的增加而增加，但对相应烯烃的选择性在3-4 wt% V原子的催化剂上达到最大。在丁烷的氧化脱氢过程中，对氧脱氢产物的选择性低于在乙烷的氧化脱氢过程中对乙烯的选择性。钒物种的类型，如VO4四面体或VO6八面体，取决于钒含量，较低的V负载量的催化剂上观察到四面体V5+物种，而较高的V负载量的催化剂上主要观察到八面体V5+物种。具有八面体V5+物种的催化剂显示出较高的催化活性，但在主要具有四面体V5+物种的催化剂上，对氧脱氢反应的选择性较高。酸位点的数量和性质，如Lewis和Brnsted酸位点，也随钒负载量的变化而变化。钒物种的类型和酸位点的性质通过影响烷烃转化的选择性和活性，对这些催化剂的工业意义有贡献。", "Doi": "10.1006/jcat.1997.1673"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"We investigate possible mechanisms of oxidative dehydrogenation of propane using density functional theory. Monomeric vanadium oxide species supported on silica are modeled by vanadyl-substituted silsesquioxane.\"\n          [2] \"The catalytic activation of CH bonds is of fundamental interest, because it is the crucial step in important technological processes and also in many enzymatic reactions.\"\n          [3] \"We examine possible reaction mechanisms for the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane by supported transition metal oxide catalysts. Specifically we are interested in V2O5 supported on SiO22,12,13 and consider monomeric OV(O)3 surface species, which together with dimeric and oligomeric V2O5 species are present on catalyst surfaces with low V2O5 loadings.\"\n          [4] \"The first hydrogen abstraction occurs exclusively on OVV sites, while the second hydrogen abstraction can also occur on VOSi bridging oxygen sites.\"\n          [5] \"The rate of propene formation after readsorption on OVV sites is much larger than the rate of isopropyl alcohol (or propene) formation after readsorption on HOVIV sites.\"\n          [6] \"With regard to the type of active oxygen species in the reaction, we find that only vanadyl sites are involved in the rate-determining step, but the second hydrogen abstraction may occur also at VOSi bridging oxygen sites without changing the overall kinetics of the reaction.\"\n          [7] \"Comparison with recent DFT calculations for V2O5(001) crystal surfaces9 indicates that vanadia sites may be significantly more active in the ODH of propane if they are part of the bulk surface and not supported as monomers on silica.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, such as supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in oxidative dehydrogenation processes. The initial step in these transformations is the activation of CH bonds, which is a crucial step in both technological processes and enzymatic reactions. For the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane, monomeric vanadium oxide species supported on silica are modeled using vanadyl-substituted silsesquioxane. The first hydrogen abstraction occurs exclusively on OVV sites, while the second hydrogen abstraction can also occur on VOSi bridging oxygen sites. The rate of propene formation after readsorption on OVV sites is much larger than the rate of isopropyl alcohol or propene formation after readsorption on HOVIV sites. Only vanadyl sites are involved in the rate-determining step, but the second hydrogen abstraction may occur also at VOSi bridging oxygen sites without changing the overall kinetics of the reaction. Vanadia sites may be significantly more active in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane if they are part of the bulk surface and not supported as monomers on silica.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件,如支撑的钒氧化物和金属交换沸石,对烷烃转化的机制和效率有重大影响,特别是在丙烷氧化脱氢等过程中。CH键的催化活化是技术过程和许多酶促反应中的关键步骤。对于丙烷的氧化脱氢,使用被钒氧基取代的倍半硅氧烷来模拟支撑在二氧化硅上的单体钒氧化物物种。第一次氢原子抽离仅发生在OVV位点,而第二次氢原子抽离也可以发生在VOSi桥接氧位点。在OVV位点重吸附后,丙烯的形成速率远大于在HOVIV位点重吸附后异丙醇或丙烯的形成速率。只有钒氧基位点参与了决定速率的步骤,但第二次氢原子抽离也可以在VOSi桥接氧位点发生,而不改变整体反应动力学。如果钒酸盐位点是体相表面的一部分,而不是作为单体支撑在二氧化硅上,它们在丙烷氧化脱氢中可能具有显著更高的活性。", "Doi": "10.1021/jp071409e"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"ZSM-5 molecular sieves with the iron and silicon tetrahedral framework were used as catalysts. The Si/Fe molar ratio was 45, 34 and 22. Fe-ZSM-5 was applied both in the sodium and hydrogen form.\"\n          [2] \"The reaction was carried out at the atmospheric pressure at 350650 8C.\"\n          [3] \"Fe-ZSM-5 consists of spherulitic aggregates. No differences in shape were observed for all the samples.\"\n          [4] \"The XRD powder patterns of the prepared Fe-HZSM-5 catalyst are presented. All the patterns of prepared zeolites exhibit the typical lines for the zeolite type ZSM-5. However, the obtained line intensities differ depending on the Fe content.\"\n          [5] \"The splitting of the reflection at 2u = 45.5 (Fig. 3) increases with increasing Si/Fe which, by analogy with the Si/Al systems consistent with the incorporation of Fe(III) into framework sites.\"\n          [6] \"The highest methane conversion amounting to 31.51% was reached while Fe-HZSM-5 with the largest iron content was applied. Increasing the iron content resulted in the rise of methane conversion.\"\n          [7] \"Introducing the sodium form of molecular sieves led to the rise in the selectivity of the oxidation of methane to oxygenates.\"\n          [8] \"The highest selectivity of methane to methanol oxidation (about 74%) was attained while a catalyst with the lowest iron content was administered.\"\n          [9] \"The increase of the temperature results in the rise of methane conversion.\"\n          [10] \"Extending the contact time and increasing the temperature resulted in lowering the selectivity of the oxidation of methane to methanol for all the catalysts.\"\n          [11] \"Methanol is produced over Fe-ZSM-5 at temperature 350 8C.\"\n          [12] \"The raise of temperature reduces methanol concentration in products because of its oxidation to formaldehyde and then to carbon dioxide.\"\n          [13] \"If Fe-HZSM-5 is applied, the oxidation of methane to methanol and to carbon dioxide follow the same speed pattern. Next, methanol slowly oxidises to formaldehyde and then to carbon dioxide.\"\n          [14] \"If Fe-NaZSM-5 has been used as a catalyst, then the methanol producing reaction is much faster than that carbon dioxide generating. However, methanol oxidises to for- maldehyde and then to carbon dioxide more rapidly than in the case of the reaction with Fe-HZSM-5 applied as a catalyst.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, such as Fe-ZSM-5, influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. The Si/Fe molar ratio, the form of Fe-ZSM-5 (sodium or hydrogen), and the temperature and contact time all play a role in the conversion of methane to methanol and carbon dioxide. The structure of Fe-ZSM-5, characterized by spherulitic aggregates and typical XRD patterns for ZSM-5, indicates the incorporation of Fe(III) into framework sites. The increase in iron content leads to higher methane conversion, while the sodium form of molecular sieves improves the selectivity of methane oxidation to oxygenates. The highest selectivity for methane to methanol oxidation is achieved with a catalyst containing the lowest iron content. Higher temperatures and longer contact times increase methane conversion but decrease the selectivity of methane oxidation to methanol. Methanol is produced at lower temperatures, but its concentration decreases at higher temperatures due to further oxidation to formaldehyde and carbon dioxide.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件，如Fe-ZSM-5，影响烷烃转化的机制和效率。催化剂中的Si/Fe摩尔比影响甲烷转化率，铁含量较高时转化率较高。催化剂的钠形式增加了甲烷氧化为含氧化合物的选择性。催化剂中存在铁影响X射线衍射图案中的线强度，表明其被纳入框架中。催化剂以球状聚集体的形式存在，铁含量影响XRD图案中的线强度。这些过程中使用的催化剂通常是具有特定结构的沸石，如ZSM-5，可以将金属离子纳入其框架中。较高的温度和较长的接触时间导致甲醇生产的选择性降低，因为甲醇进一步氧化为甲醛和二氧化碳。这些过程中使用的催化剂通常是具有特定结构的沸石，如ZSM-5，可以将金属离子纳入其框架中。然而，这些过程的效率受到催化剂组成、结构和反应条件的影响，必须优化以获得最大产量和选择性。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.apcata.2004.09.005"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The majority of papers focus on some specific aspects that may affect the reactivity of the catalysts investigated. For instance, in the case of supported metal oxide catalysts, in addition to the usual morphological aspects, some of the important features affecting the performance are: the degree of agglomeration of Me cations (from isolated units to bulk Me oxide); acidbase characteristics; the valence state of the metal cation under reaction conditions; the collective electronic properties of the solid.\"\n          [2] \"In propane ODH, the catalytic activity of vanadium oxide catalysts increases with the V2O5 loading, while rates per V- atom reach a maximum on VOx domains of intermediate size, providing a balance between the activity of surface VOx species and their accessibility to reactants.\"\n          [3] \"The selectivity to the corresponding olefins shows a peak for intermediate values of active phase loading, which corresponds to the development of the monolayer structure.\"\n          [4] \"The extent of V reduction during steady-state ODH is much lower than for stoichiometric reduction of V5+ to V4+ or V3+.\"\n          [5] \"The number of catalytically significant reduced centers depends only on alkane/O2 ratios.\"\n          [6] \"The fraction of V-atoms that exist as catalytically reduced centers increases with increasing vanadia surface density and domain size up to surface densities typical of polyvanadate monolayers, and then reaches nearly constant values at higher surface densities;therefore, both isolated and polymeric species are active, but polymerized surface VO4 species are more extensively reduced than the isolated species during steady-state alkane oxidation.\"\n          [7] \"The selectivity to propylene formation is affected by surface reduction: the higher the surface reduction, the higher the selectivity.\"\n          [8] \"The use of N2O to replace O2 causes the development of a more reduced, and more selective, surface.\"\n          [9] \"The extent of reduction of the surface V5+ species also depends on the specific oxide support: V2O5-ZrO2 > V2O5-Al2O3 > V2O5-SiO2; the reac- tivity, TOF, in ethane ODH follows the same ranking.\"\n          [10] \"The role of the support on the reactivity of vanadium oxide in alkane ODH has been investigated by many authors.\"\n          [11] \"In general, in propane ODH catalysts made of Voxide supported on silica are more selective than those made with the alumina support, and the latter are more selective than those supported on titania, mainly because of the lower extent of parallel propane combustion, especially at low vanadia loading.\"\n          [12] \"The reduction and catalytic properties of active VOx domains can be significantly affected by the formation of binary dispersed structures.\"\n          [13] \"Additives (e.g., P, K, Ca, Ni, Cr, Nb, Mg, Au, Zn and Mo), sometimes added in relevant amount with respect to V,modify acidbasic and redox properties of supported vanadium oxide.\"\n          [14] \"Modification of these properties affects catalytic performance in ODH; in samples where an increase of the concentration of acid sites is observed (due to the increase in the electronegativity of the additive ions), the total activity increases.\"\n          [15] \"The addition of alkali and alkaline earth dopants decreases the activity and increases the selectivity to propylene in propane ODH.\"\n          [16] \"The order of the increasing selectivities to propylene in propane ODH follows the order of the increasing basicity and the increasing MO bond energy.\"\n          [17] \"A key factor in the design of efficient catalysts for alkane ODH is the isolation of active sites.\"\n          [18] \"Therefore, the isomorphous substitution of active metal species,e.g.,vanadium, into microporous and mesoporous materials is an attractive strategy for designing new catalysts for this reaction.\"\n          [19] \"The main drawback of these systems is that they do not always maintain the structure if high V contents are incorporated; furthermore, the incorporated V species may sometimes be easily withdrawn from the structure during the reaction.\"\n          [20] \"In the case of VCoAPO-18, the presence of both acid sites (related to the presence of Co2+ cations) and redox sites (related to the presence of V5+/4+ and Co3+/2+) seems to be an important factor in achieving high selectivities to ethylene during the ODH of ethane.\"\n          [21] \"One of the best performing catalysts in propane ODH is the VOx-SBA-15 system, prepared by an alcoholic impregnation method, in which the introduction of V species onto the inner walls of SBA-15 provides a system with a large concentration of accessible, isolated and structurally well- defined active sites.\"\n          [22] \"In general, catalysts are less active than vanadia-based catalysts, regardless of the support used.\"\n          [23] \"Propane ODH rates per Mo atom increase with increasing Mo surface density and reach a maximum value for samples with 4.5 Mo/nm2; this behavior reflects an increase in the reactivity of surface Mo species.\"\n          [24] \"The size of MoOx domains also affects the Mo O strength; stronger Mo O bonds show lower ODH activity.\"\n          [25] \"The presence of alkali (Cs, K, Li) affects the structure of MoOx domains and influences their electronic and catalytic properties.\"\n          [26] \"Propane ODH turnover rates decreases monotonically while increasing both the dopant/Mo atomic ratio and the basicity of the alkali oxide (Cs > K > Li).\"\n          [27] \"These basic oxides inhibit the initial reduction of MoOx by strengthening MoO bonds; as a result, rate-determining CH bond activation step, which involves the local reduction of Mo centers, proceed more slowly.\"\n          [28] \"The stronger inhibition of secondary propylene combustion reflects the weaker Lewis acidity of Mo sites when modified by the basic dopants; this accounts for the higher selectivity to propylene.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. Important features affecting the performance include the degree of agglomeration of metal cations, acid-base characteristics, the valence state of the metal cation under reaction conditions, and the collective electronic properties of the solid. In propane oxidative dehydrogenation, the catalytic activity of vanadium oxide catalysts increases with the V2O5 loading, while rates per vanadium atom reach a maximum on VOx domains of intermediate size, providing a balance between the activity of surface VOx species and their accessibility to reactants. The selectivity to olefins peaks at intermediate values of active phase loading, corresponding to the development of the monolayer structure. The extent of vanadium reduction during steady-state oxidative dehydrogenation is much lower than for stoichiometric reduction of V5+ to V4+ or V3+. The number of catalytically significant reduced centers depends on alkane/O2 ratios. Both isolated and polymeric species are active, but polymerized surface VO4 species are more extensively reduced than isolated species during steady-state alkane oxidation. Surface reduction affects the selectivity to propylene formation: the higher the surface reduction, the higher the selectivity. The use of N2O instead of O2 causes the development of a more reduced and more selective surface. The extent of reduction of the surface V5+ species also depends on the specific oxide support. The role of the support on the reactivity of vanadium oxide in alkane oxidative dehydrogenation has been extensively studied. Catalysts made of vanadium oxide supported on silica are more selective than those made with alumina support, which are more selective than those supported on titania, mainly due to the lower extent of parallel propane combustion, especially at low vanadia loading. The reduction and catalytic properties of active VOx domains can be significantly affected by the formation of binary dispersed structures. The selectivity to propylene can be correlated with the work function values. The relatively inert secondary surface metal oxide additives are able to weakly adsorb propane in a precursor state that supplies the catalytic active VOx sites for propane activation to propylene. With different metal oxides, turnover rates reflect CH bond cleavage activation energies, influenced by the reducibility of these metal oxides. Additives modify the acid-base and redox properties of supported vanadium oxide, affecting catalytic performance in oxidative dehydrogenation. The addition of alkali and alkaline earth dopants decreases activity and increases selectivity to propylene in propane oxidative dehydrogenation. The order of increasing selectivities to propylene in propane oxidative dehydrogenation follows the order of increasing basicity and increasing MO bond energy. The basicity of the support greatly affects selectivity. The use of a basic metal oxide support results in improved selectivity due to the possible rapid desorption of the electron-rich propylene product before further combustion to COx. In the case of VCoAPO-18, the presence of both acid sites and redox sites seems to be an important factor in achieving high selectivities to ethylene during the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane. In general, catalysts based on supported molybdenum oxide are less active than vanadia-based catalysts, regardless of the support used. Propane oxidative dehydrogenation rates per molybdenum atom increase with increasing Mo surface density and reach a maximum value for samples with 4.5 Mo/nm2, reflecting an increase in the reactivity of surface Mo species. The size of MoOx domains affects the Mo O strength; stronger Mo O bonds show lower oxidative dehydrogenation activity. The presence of alkali affects the structure of MoOx domains and influences their electronic and catalytic properties. Propane oxidative dehydrogenation turnover rates decrease monotonically with increasing dopant/Mo atomic ratio and the basicity of the alkali oxide. These basic oxides inhibit the initial reduction of MoOx by strengthening MoO bonds, resulting in slower rate-determining CH bond activation steps involving the local reduction of Mo centers. The stronger inhibition of secondary propylene combustion reflects the weaker Lewis acidity of Mo sites when modified by basic dopants, accounting for the higher selectivity to propylene.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件，包括负载型钒氧化物和金属交换沸石，对烷烃转化的机制和效率有重大影响。影响催化剂性能的重要特征包括金属阳离子的聚集程度、酸碱特性、反应条件下金属阳离子的价态以及固体的集体电子性质。在丙烷氧化脱氢中，钒氧化物催化剂的催化活性随着V2O5负载量的增加而增加，而每钒原子的速率在VOx域的中间大小时达到最大，这在表面VOx物种的活性和它们对反应物的可及性之间提供了平衡。对相应烯烃的选择性在活性相负载的中间值时达到峰值，这对应于单层结构的形成。在稳态氧化脱氢期间，钒的还原程度远低于V5+到V4+或V3+的计量还原。催化显著还原中心的数量仅取决于烷烃/O2比率。孤立和聚合物种都是活性的，但在稳态烷烃氧化期间，聚合表面VO4物种比孤立物种更广泛地还原。表面还原影响丙烯形成的选择性：表面还原程度越高，选择性越高。使用N2O代替O2会导致更还原和更具选择性的表面的形成。表面V5+物种的还原程度也取决于特定的氧化物载体。载体对钒氧化物在烷烃氧化脱氢中的反应性的作用已被广泛研究。由负载在二氧化硅上的钒氧化物制成的催化剂比那些使用氧化铝载体的催化剂更具选择性，而后者比那些使用二氧化钛的催化剂更具选择性，这主要是由于在较低的钒酸盐负载下，平行丙烷燃烧的程度较低。VOx域的还原和催化性质可以显著受到二元分散结构的形成的影响。丙烯的选择性也可以与功函数值相关联。相对惰性的二次表面金属氧化物添加剂能够弱吸附丙烷，以一种前体状态供给催化活性VOx位点，用于丙烷活化为丙烯。使用不同的金属氧化物，周转率反映了CH键断裂活化能，这些活化能受到这些金属氧化物的还原性的影晌。添加剂修改了负载型钒氧化物的酸碱性和氧化还原性质，影响了氧化脱氢中的催化性能。添加碱金属和碱土金属掺杂剂降低了活性，增加了丙烷氧化脱氢中对丙烯的选择性。丙烷氧化脱氢中对丙烯的增加选择性的顺序遵循增加的碱性和增加的MO键能的顺序。载体的碱性可能极大地影响选择性。使用碱性金属氧化物载体由于可能快速脱附电子丰富的丙烯产物，从而避免进一步燃烧为COx，从而提高了选择性。在VCoAPO-18的情况下，酸性位点（与Co2+阳离子的存在有关）和氧化还原位点（与V5+/4+和Co3+/2+的存在有关）的存在似乎是实现高选择性到乙烯在乙烷氧化脱氢期间的一个重要因素。一般来说，基于负载型钼氧化物的催化剂，无论使用何种载体，其活性都低于基于钒的催化剂。每钼原子的丙烷氧化脱氢速率随着Mo表面密度的增加而增加，并且对于具有4.5 Mo/nm2的样品达到最大值，这反映了表面Mo物种反应性的增加。MoOx域的大小也影响Mo O强度；更强的Mo O键显示出较低的氧化脱氢活性。碱金属（Cs、K、Li）的存在影响MoOx域的结构，并影响其电子和催化性质。丙烷氧化脱氢周转率随着掺杂剂/Mo原子比和碱性氧化物的碱性增加而单调下降。这些碱性氧化物通过增强MoO键来抑制MoOx的初始还原；结果，涉及Mo中心局部还原的决定速率的CH键活化步骤进行得更慢。二次丙烯燃烧的更强抑制反映了当用碱性掺杂剂改性时Mo位点的较弱Lewis酸性；这解释了对丙烯的更高选择性。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.cattod.2007.05.009"},
{"Quotes": "The recent results of Maleic Anhydride Synthesis from C , Hydrocarbons u . These experimental results illustrate the important relationship between catalytic behavior and the surface modifications induced by the medium itself. The redox properties of the feed influence the surface oxidation state of the catalyst, which in turn profoundly affects the nature of the products formed in the reaction. The change of valence state of vanadium thus de- pends upon a balance of three factors: (1) the redox potential of the feed, (2) the rate of oxidation of the catalyst at the temperature of reaction, and (3) the rate of reduction of the catalyst at the temperature of re- action. However, a deeper examination of the dy- namics of the working state of the catalyst surface and the relationship between surface-induced modifications and catalytic behavior would lead to an even better understanding of the selectivity-controlling properties of these mixed oxides. The results of surface modifications induced by the interaction of C4 hydrocarbons as well as the results of P:V ratio effect on redox properties and on selectivity/activity are in- terpreted on the basis of two different types of reaction in going from the alkane or alkene to maleic anhydride:a first step of oxidative dehydrogenation up to adsorbed butadiene and a second step of further oxidation of this intermediate. The first step is suggested to be con- trolled by the rate of Vw reduction, whereas the second step is controlled by the amount of Vv available. However, when the content of Vv is too high, the oxi- dation proceeds further to carbon oxides. These data suggest a strong relationship between selectivity to maleic anhydride at high conversion and rate of formation of vanadium(V). The different redox properties of the three catalysts (only crystalhe phase, the va- nadyl pyrophosphate) depend upon the preparation procedures. At low conversion and similar rates of Vv formation the catalysts show approximately similar selectivity, but at high conversion, when the greatest disparity in rates of oxidation exists, the more oxidiz- able catalyst shows the highest rate of maleic anhydride decomposition. The vanadium phosphorus oxide system is characterized by facile formation and interconversion of a number of crystal- line V(IV) and V(V) phases, and this has led to some confusion in the literature as to the nature of the active phase. In the PVO system, there are many synthesis variables that affect the solid-state chemistry leading to the active catalyst, and thus the performance char- acteristics and mechanism of catalysis. For example, the use of an organic solvent during preparation as opposed to an aqueous system results in differing de- grees of crystallinity and defect structure of the re- sulting active phase. The final P V ratio of the active phase may he varied and has been the subject of nu- merous publication. However, recent advances in understanding the sol- id-state chemistry of PVO have allowed studies of this reaction with well-characterized, reproducible compo- sitions. This has resulted in better analysis of the role of oxidation states, the P V ratio, and defect structure on the reaction mechanism. The n-butane to maleic anhydride reaction is a fas- cinating and complex system. This catalytic system performs a 14-electron oxidation involving the ab- straction of 8 hydrogen atoms and insertion of 3 oxygen atoms. The vanadium phosphorus oxide system is characterized by the facile formation of a number of crystalline phases, both of vanadium(IV) and vanadium(V), with the more interesting P:V atomic ratio near 1.0. The vanadyl orthophosphate crystal structure consists of V06 and PO4 groups arranged in layers [VOP04],, held together by long V-0 bonds or by hydrogen bonds. The layered structure leads to a rich intercalation chemistry, with the formation of layered solids consisting of alternating inorganic and organic layers or the formation of sol- vated inorganic intercalation compound. The constitutive layers of the y-VOP04 framework have a tenden@ to shift cooperatively along the Burger vector in order to progressively form the columns of edge-share octahedra and pyrophosphate groups of (VO)2P207. This trans- formation is easier than the movement along the crys- tallographic shear planes proposed to account for the reduction of p-VOP04. a-VOP04 reduces under less severe conditions compared to p-VOP04, but it can also transform to p-VOP04 at high temperatures, particularly in the hot-spot zones of fixed-bed reactors. The presence of p-VOP04 in used or inactive catalysts for butane oxidation accounts for a loss of catalytic per- formance, and its greater stability compared with that of the other forms of VOP04 limits its further trans- formation. The active catalyst must possess an optimal V4+/V5+ ratio for selectivity in n-butane oxidation according to Zazhigalov et al. from studies of V/P-mica com- pounds with variable V(IV)/V(V) ratios. These com- pounds preserve the layer structure of the initial a- V5+OP04 compound. Optimal performance properties are associated with catalysts containing 4-9 V(V) ions per V(1V) ion. The results of Contractor et al., Johnson et al., Pepera et al., and Trifirb et a1. agree with the identification of vanadyl pyrophosphate as the active phase in n-butane oxidation. Contractor et al. indicate that in the absence of gas-phase oxygen it is possible to eliminate highly active surface oxygen species that are not selective. Using a recirculating solids reactor, with separate hydrocarbon-catalyst and oxygen-catalyst stages, it is possible to increase the selectivity to maleic anhydride to near 80%. The P:V ratio is a key parameter in determining catalyst selectivity and activity according to Wenig and S h r a d e r . Selectivity for maleic anhydride increases with catalyst phosphorus loading, whereas specific ac- tivity of both selective and nonselective oxidation de- creases on increase of phosphorus content in the 0.9-1.2 P:V range. Best catalytic performances are exhibited with a catalyst with a P:V ratio of 1.1. The vanadium phosphorus oxides are able to dehydrogenate the n-butane to olefins, and these olefins react further to form partial oxidation producta. When insufficient oxygen is channeled to the active site,intermediate products may desorb and react at other sites. When surface oxygen concentrations are high, the evidence supports a single-site mechanism for selective conversion of n-butane to maleic anhydride; Le., once n-butane is activated, it remains bound to the surface in various forms until desorption as maleic anhydride occurs. The very different kinetic behaviors of the alkene and alkane reactants bring into question the different cat- alyst surface effects induced by the two reactants. Szakacs et al. studied the oxidation of but-l-ene and n-butane to maleic anhydride in a pulse micro- reactor in the presence of gaseous O2 on a VOP04 catalyst. Oxygen balances show that in both cases, in spite of the presence of gas-phase 02, the Vv phosphate acts as the oxygen source. However, in the but-l-ene conversion the amount of lattice oxygen incorporated in the products of reaction is much higher than in the n-butane case, pointing out the substantial difference in the reactivity and of the type of interaction of the two hydrocarbons.", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. The redox properties of the feed influence the surface oxidation state of the catalyst, which in turn affects the nature of the products formed in the reaction. The change of valence state of vanadium depends on the redox potential of the feed, the rate of oxidation of the catalyst at the reaction temperature, and the rate of reduction of the catalyst at the reaction temperature. A deeper examination of the dynamics of the working state of the catalyst surface and the relationship between surface-induced modifications and catalytic behavior would lead to a better understanding of the selectivity-controlling properties of these mixed oxides. The results of surface modifications induced by the interaction of C4 hydrocarbons as well as the results of P:V ratio effect on redox properties and on selectivity/activity are interpreted on the basis of two different types of reaction in going from the alkane or alkene to maleic anhydride: a first step of oxidative dehydrogenation up to adsorbed butadiene and a second step of further oxidation of this intermediate. The first step is controlled by the rate of Vw reduction, whereas the second step is controlled by the amount of Vv available. However, when the content of Vv is too high, the oxidation proceeds further to carbon oxides. There is a strong relationship between selectivity to maleic anhydride at high conversion and the rate of formation of vanadium(V). The different redox properties of the three catalysts depend on the preparation procedures. At low conversion and similar rates of Vv formation, the catalysts show approximately similar selectivity, but at high conversion, when the greatest disparity in rates of oxidation exists, the more oxidizable catalyst shows the highest rate of maleic anhydride decomposition. The vanadium phosphorus oxide (PVO) system, for instance, is characterized by the facile formation and interconversion of various crystalline V(IV) and V(V) phases, leading to confusion about the nature of the active phase. The synthesis variables, such as the use of organic solvents versus aqueous systems, affect the crystallinity and defect structure of the active phase. The final P:V ratio of the active phase, which has been the subject of numerous publications, also plays a crucial role. Recent advances in understanding the solid-state chemistry of PVO have allowed for the study of reactions with well-characterized, reproducible compositions, leading to better analysis of the role of oxidation states, the P:V ratio, and defect structure on the reaction mechanism. The n-butane to maleic anhydride reaction, a complex system involving a 14-electron oxidation, is influenced by the nature of the active site, the importance of the P:V ratio, oxidation state, and structural characteristics of the vanadium phosphorus oxide system. The detection and formation of intermediates are also critical factors. The PVO system exhibits a rich intercalation chemistry, with the formation of layered solids consisting of alternating inorganic and organic layers or solvated inorganic intercalation compounds. The stability and reactivity of different PVO phases, such as a-VOP04 and p-VOP04, affect catalytic performance, with p-VOP04 being less stable and more prone to transformation at high temperatures, leading to a loss of catalytic performance. The optimal V4+/V5+ ratio for selectivity in n-butane oxidation is crucial, with catalysts containing 4-9 V(V) ions per V(IV) ion showing optimal performance properties. The identification of vanadyl pyrophosphate as the active phase in n-butane oxidation has been supported by various studies. The P:V ratio is a key parameter in determining catalyst selectivity and activity, with selectivity for maleic anhydride increasing with higher phosphorus loading, while specific activity decreases. The vanadium phosphorus oxides can dehydrogenate n-butane to olefins, which then react further to form partial oxidation products. The mechanism of selective conversion of n-butane to maleic anhydride is supported by high surface oxygen concentrations, indicating a single-site mechanism. In the oxidation of C4 alkenes, an interesting effect is observed: increasing hydrocarbon concentration initially increases the formation of maleic anhydride to a maximum, followed by a decrease with a corresponding increase in butadiene formation. The different kinetic behaviors of alkene and alkane reactants suggest different catalyst surface effects. Oxygen balances in the oxidation of but-1-ene and n-butane to maleic anhydride show that, despite the presence of gas-phase O2, the Vv phosphate acts as the oxygen source. However, the amount of lattice oxygen incorporated in the products of reaction is higher in the but-1-ene conversion than in the n-butane case, highlighting the difference in reactivity and interaction of the two hydrocarbons.", "Chinese": "所有答案结果中的汇总中文答案 1", "Doi": "10.1021/cr00083a003"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Zn- or Ga-modified zeolites effectively catalyze the conversion of light alkanes to aromatics with high selectivity.\"\n          [2] \"The role of the metal species and acid sites of a zeolite in the enhancement of light alkane conversion to aromatics remains a subject of intense controversy.\"\n          [3] \"On the one hand, there is agreement on the bifunctional nature of these catalysts, where the metal species are responsible for the dehydrogenation of alkanes, while the Brnsted acid sites are involved in the oligomerization and cyclization of olefins.\"\n          [4] \"On the other hand, it has been claimed that the activation and cleavage of CH bonds of alkanes occurs predominantly at the Brnsted acid sites.\"\n          [5] \"Ga or Zn act as portholes and catalyze the recombinative desorption of H atoms, formed from acid-catalyzed CH bond cleavage, as dihydrogen (H2).\"\n          [6] \"Desorption of hydrogen species shifts the equilibrium towards the formation of olefins and suppresses hydrogen transfer to hydrocarbon species, leading to ethane and methane.\"\n          [7] \"Further olefin oligomerization and dehydrocyclization give aromatic species.\"\n          [8] \"The activation of the alkane by the Brnsted acid sites is assumed to be independent of metal species present in zeolites.\"\n          [9] \"A significant increase in the reaction rates with lowering apparent activation energies demonstrate the promoting effect of Zn on the reaction of H/D hydrogen exchange for C1n-C4 alkanes.\"\n          [10] \"The acceleration of H/D exchange, coupled with the decreased activation energy for Zn-modified zeolites, demonstrates that the CH bonds in alkanes break and form more easily and reversibly with intermediate involvement of Zn species.\"\n          [11] \"The influence of Zn on alkane activation has been rationalized by dissociative adsorption of alkanes on Zn oxide species inside zeolite pores, which precedes the interaction of alkane with Brnsted acid sites.\"\n          [12] \"The intermediate formation of an olefin during dehydrogenation on Zn cations, representing the Lewis acid sites, or the involvement of Zn alkyl species, formed by the dissociative adsorption of the alkane.\"\n          [13] \"The possibility of the formation of Zn-alkyl species upon alkane adsorption on Zn-modified zeolites was concluded from IR studies earlier.\"\n          [14] \"For zeolites with a high Zn content (78 wt%, in our case), the formation of a Zn alkyl species presumably occurs at small ZnO clusters existing inside the zeolite pores.\"\n          [15] \"Dissociative adsorption of the deuterated alkane on Zn oxide sites, which precedes H/D exchange, leads to Znalkyl species and ZnOD groups.\"\n          [16] \"Protonation of the Znalkyl species by the vicinal acidic OH group of the zeolite with synchronous reverse transfer of the deuterium from the ZnOD to the zeolite acid site, finally provide a transfer of protium from the SiOHAl group of the zeolite to the deuterated alkane molecule.\"\n          [17] \"The mechanism also rationalizes the involvement of only the methyl groups of C3 and n-C4 alkanes in the exchange.\"\n          [18] \"It becomes clear from our data that the activation of CH bonds of small alkanes by zeolite Brnsted acid sites depends on Zn species, which form an intermediate with the alkane.\"\n          [19] \"One can assume that the interaction of the Znalkyl species with zeolite acid sites can provide not only the H/D exchange reaction, but also a dehydrogenation step, yielding olefins for the subsequent aromatization steps.\"\n          [20] \"Synergetic action of Zn and Brnsted sites in enhancing aromatization ability could be achieved by involvement in the activation of the alkane CH bond of both the zeolite acid OH groups and the Zn alkyl species formed on Zn sites.\"\n          [21] \"The intermediate or transition state, which involves the zeolite acid sites and the alkane-and-Zn sites leads to alkane dehydrogenationpresumably by the energetically most favorable way.\"\n          [22] \"The enhancement of alkane conversion towards the formation of aromatic molecules on Zn-modified zeolites could be achieved.\"\n          [23] \"The effect of Zn, which earlier was attributed either to the dehydrogenation ability of the loaded metal or its ability to afford the recombinative desorption of H atoms, is shown to be the direct influence of Zn on the activation of alkane CH bonds by the catalysts Brnsted acid sites.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. Zn- or Ga-modified zeolites effectively catalyze the conversion of light alkanes to aromatics with high selectivity. The role of metal species and acid sites in enhancing light alkane conversion to aromatics is a subject of intense controversy. Metal species are responsible for the dehydrogenation of alkanes, while Brnsted acid sites are involved in the oligomerization and cyclization of olefins. The activation and cleavage of CH bonds of alkanes occur predominantly at the Brnsted acid sites. Ga or Zn act as portholes and catalyze the recombinative desorption of H atoms, formed from acid-catalyzed CH bond cleavage, as dihydrogen (H2). Desorption of hydrogen species shifts the equilibrium towards the formation of olefins and suppresses hydrogen transfer to hydrocarbon species, leading to ethane and methane. Further olefin oligomerization and dehydrocyclization give aromatic species. The activation of the alkane by the Brnsted acid sites is assumed to be independent of metal species present in zeolites. Zn has a promoting effect on the reaction of H/D hydrogen exchange for C1n-C4 alkanes, increasing the reaction rates and lowering apparent activation energies. The CH bonds in alkanes break and form more easily and reversibly with intermediate involvement of Zn species. The influence of Zn on alkane activation is rationalized by dissociative adsorption of alkanes on Zn oxide species inside zeolite pores, which precedes the interaction of alkane with Brnsted acid sites. The intermediate formation of an olefin during dehydrogenation on Zn cations or the involvement of Zn alkyl species, formed by the dissociative adsorption of the alkane, is possible. The formation of Zn-alkyl species upon alkane adsorption on Zn-modified zeolites has been concluded from IR studies. For zeolites with a high Zn content, the formation of a Zn alkyl species occurs at small ZnO clusters inside the zeolite pores. Dissociative adsorption of the deuterated alkane on Zn oxide sites leads to Znalkyl species and ZnOD groups. Protonation of the Znalkyl species by the vicinal acidic OH group of the zeolite provides a transfer of protium from the SiOHAl group of the zeolite to the deuterated alkane molecule. The mechanism rationalizes the involvement of only the methyl groups of C3 and n-C4 alkanes in the exchange. The activation of CH bonds of small alkanes by zeolite Brnsted acid sites depends on Zn species, which form an intermediate with the alkane. The interaction of the Znalkyl species with zeolite acid sites can provide not only the H/D exchange reaction but also a dehydrogenation step, yielding olefins for the subsequent aromatization steps. Synergetic action of Zn and Brnsted sites in enhancing aromatization ability could be achieved by involvement in the activation of the alkane CH bond of both the zeolite acid OH groups and the Zn alkyl species formed on Zn sites. The intermediate or transition state, which involves the zeolite acid sites and the alkane-and-Zn sites leads to alkane dehydrogenation. The enhancement of alkane conversion towards the formation of aromatic molecules on Zn-modified zeolites could be achieved. The effect of Zn on the activation of alkane CH bonds by the catalysts Brnsted acid sites is shown to be the direct influence of Zn.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件，包括支撑的钒氧化物和金属交换沸石，对烷烃转化的机制和效率有重大影响。Zn-或Ga改性的沸石能有效地催化轻烷烃向芳烃的转化，具有高选择性。金属物种和酸位点在增强轻烷烃向芳烃的转化中的作用仍然是一个有争议的话题。金属物种负责烷烃的脱氢，而Brnsted酸位点则参与烯烃的寡聚和环化。烷烃的CH键的活化和裂解主要发生在Brnsted酸位点。Ga或Zn作为端口，催化H原子的重组解吸，形成二氢（H2）。氢物种的解吸使烯烃的形成平衡向正方向移动，抑制了向烃类物种的氢转移，导致乙烷和甲烷的形成。进一步的烯烃寡聚和脱氢环化产生芳烃物种。烷烃在沸石Brnsted酸位点的活化被假定为独立于沸石中存在的金属物种。Zn对C1n-C4烷烃的H/D氢交换反应有促进作用，显著提高了反应速率，降低了表观活化能。Zn物种的中间参与使烷烃中的CH键更容易和可逆地断裂和形成。在Zn改性沸石上的烷烃吸附可以形成Zn-烷基物种，这被IR研究得出结论。对于Zn含量高的沸石，Zn烷基物种的形成发生在沸石孔内的小ZnO簇中。在Zn氧化物位点上对氘化烷烃的解离吸附导致Znalkyl物种和ZnOD基团的形成。Znalkyl物种通过沸石的邻近酸性OH基团的质子化，伴随着从ZnOD到沸石酸位点的氘的逆向转移，最终提供了从沸石的SiOHAl基团到氘化烷烃分子的质子转移。该机制也解释了只有C3和n-C4烷烃的甲基基团参与交换的现象。从我们的数据中可以清楚地看出，沸石Brnsted酸位点对小烷烃的CH键的活化依赖于与烷烃形成中间体的Zn物种。可以假设，Znalkyl物种与沸石酸位点的相互作用不仅可以提供H/D交换反应，还可以提供一个脱氢步骤，产生烯烃，用于随后的芳构化步骤。Zn和Brnsted位点在增强芳构化能力方面的协同作用可以通过在Zn位点形成的Zn烷基物种和沸石酸OH基团的参与来实现，以激活烷烃的CH键。涉及沸石酸位点和烷烃和Zn位点的中间体或过渡态导致烷烃的脱氢，可能是通过能量最有利的方式。Zn改性沸石上烷烃向芳烃分子的转化的增强是可以实现的。Zn对催化剂Brnsted酸位点的烷烃CH键的活化的影响被证明是Zn的直接影响。", "Doi": "10.1002/cphc.200800569"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Supported vanadium oxide in heterogeneous catalysis:elucidating the structureactivity relationship with spectroscopy Ilke Muylaert and Pascal Van Der Voort,  Phys. Chem. Chem.
