Phys., 2009\"\n          [3] \"Although earlier isolated mononuclear GaO+ have been proposed as the active sites in Ga-containing high-silica zeolites,13,1621 the present results indicate that such species should oligomerize in the microporous space, independent of the Al distribution. The driving force is the formation of multinuclear oxygenated gallium species with a more optimal coordination of the metal centers.\"\n          [4] \"Binuclear galliumoxo cationic species show significant reactivity toward heterolytic CH cleavage. Catalytic dehydro- genation of ethane over the Ga2O2 proceeds via initial heterolytic dissociation by the Lewis acidbase pair formed by the Ga3+ and the basic extraframework oxygen atom followed by olefin desorption and hydrogen recombination.\"\n          [5] \"The decreased basicity of the extraframework oxygen and the stable tetrahedral coordination of Ga3+ in the dimeric species facilitate H2 desorption. However, hydrogenation of the cluster in principle opens a pathway to its decomposition via water desorption, resulting in less reactive reduced sites.\"\n          [6] \"Such insight predicts that addition of water to the hydrocarbon feed increases the steady-state concentration of the reactive oxygenated extraframework species.\"\n          [7] \"Catalytic experiments support well this proposal: a substantial increase in the dehydrogenation activity of Ga+/ZSM-5 zeolite is observed upon water co-feeding.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, such as supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. Spectroscopy elucidates the structure-activity relationship, crucial for understanding and optimizing catalytic performance. For metal-exchanged zeolites, the reactivity in confined spaces is studied through the interplay between spectroscopy and theory, leading to the development of structure-activity relationships for catalysis. The stability and reactivity of extraframework metal-containing cationic species in high-silica zeolites are governed by factors such as the coordination environment and the necessity to compensate for positive extraframework charges. The formation of multinuclear oxygenated gallium species with optimal coordination of metal centers is a driving force for oligomerization of isolated mononuclear GaO+ species in microporous space. Binuclear gallium-oxo cationic species exhibit significant reactivity toward heterolytic CH cleavage, facilitating catalytic dehydrogenation of ethane. The decreased basicity of extraframework oxygen and stable tetrahedral coordination of Ga3+ in dimeric species promote H2 desorption. However, hydrogenation of the cluster can lead to its decomposition via water desorption, resulting in less reactive reduced sites. The addition of water to the hydrocarbon feed increases the steady-state concentration of reactive oxygenated extraframework species, as supported by catalytic experiments showing a substantial increase in dehydrogenation activity of Ga+/ZSM-5 zeolite upon water co-feeding. These factors contribute to the industrial significance of metal-based catalysts in alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件,如支撑的钒氧化物和金属交换沸石,对烷烃转化的机理和效率有重大影响,特别是在氧化脱氢和沸石催化反应等过程中,而这些因素对它们的工业意义至关重要。通过光谱学,结构-活性关系得以阐明,这有助于理解在像沸石这样的受限空间中的催化行为。例如,在高硅莫来石中,环状Ga2O2 2+离子比孤立的GaO+离子更稳定,导致对异裂CH断裂的增强反应性。Ga2O2上的乙烷催化脱氢通过初始异裂解离进行,随后是烯烃解吸和氢重组。额外框架氧的碱性降低和Ga3+离子的稳定四面体配位促进了H2解吸。然而,簇的氢化原则上开辟了一条通过水解吸导致其分解的途径,导致活性降低的还原位点。预测向碳氢化合物进料中添加水会增加反应性氧化额外框架物种的稳态浓度。催化实验很好地支持了这一提议:在水共进料时,观察到Ga+/ZSM-5沸石的脱氢活性显著增加。", "Doi": "10.1039/b815943b"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Supported vanadium oxide catalysts, containing surface vanadia species on oxide supports, are extensively employed as catalysts for many hydrocarbon oxidation reactions.\"\n          [2] \"This paper discusses the current fundamental information available about the structure and reactivity of surface vanadia species on oxide supports: monolayer surface coverage, stability of the surface vanadia monolayer,oxidation state of the surface vanadia species, molecular structures of the surface vanadia species (as a function of environment and catalyst composition), acidity of the surface vanadia species and reactivity of the surface vanadia species.\"\n          [3] \"Comparison of the molecular structure and reactivity information provides new fundamental insights into the catalytic properties of surface vanadia species during hydrocarbon oxidation reactions: (1) the role of terminal V=O, bridging V-O-V and bridging V-O-support bonds, (2) the number of surface vanadia sites required, (3) the influence of metal oxide additives, (4) the influence of surface acidic and basic sites, (5) the influence of preparation methods and (6) the influence of the specific oxide support phase.\"\n          [4] \"The unique physical and chemical characteristics of supported vanadia catalysts, compared to other supported metal oxide catalysts, for hydrocarbon oxidation reactions are also discussed.\"\n          [5] \"The surface vanadia monolayer is stable after its initial formation on many typical oxide supports (A1203, TiO2, ZrO2, Nb205 and CeO2).\"\n          [6] \"The surface vanadia monolayer on oxide supports is also stable under reducing and reaction environ- ments.\"\n          [7] \"The stability of the surface vanadia monolayers is reflected in the long life of such industrial oxidation catalysts.\"\n          [8] \"The molecular structures of the surface vanadia species have been extensively investigated in the past few years with many different spectroscopies.\"\n          [9] \"The molecular structures of these surface vanadia species are tentatively thought to consist of a terminal V=O bond and three bridging V-O-support bonds for the isolated species, and a terminal V=O bond with one bridging V-O-support and two bridging V-O-V bonds for the polymerized species.\"\n          [10] \"The molecular structures of the surface vanadia species are determined by the net pH of the aqueous thin film, which depends on the surface point of zero charge of the oxide support and the amount of the surface vanadia species.\"\n          [11] \"The hydration-dehydration processes of the supported vanadia catalysts are completely reversible.\"\n          [12] \"Exposure of the surface vanadia (5+) species to reducing H2 and CO environ- ments results in the formation of surface vanadia (4+) and vanadia (3+) species.\"\n          [13] \"Direct information about the molecular structures of the reduced surface vanadia species can be obtained from in situ EPR for isolated V(4+) [2,47,57], and UV- VIS DRS measurements for V(4+,3+) [47,56,57] and XANES/EXAFS for V(4+,3) (no known studies at this point).\"\n          [14] \"The influence of hydrocarbon oxidation reaction environments upon the oxida- tion states of the surface vanadia species in supported vanadia catalysts has been examined for several reactions with in situ Raman spectroscopy.\"\n          [15] \"The in situ Raman studies provide new insights into the behavior of surface vanadia species during hydrocarbon oxidation reactions: (1) the dehydrated V(5) surface vanadia species appears to be the predominant surface vanadia species, (2) the extent of reduction of the surface vanadia species depends on the reducing power of the hydrocarbon (methanol> butene>butane>methane), (3) the specific oxide support and (4) the ratio of polymerized to isolated surface vanadia species (polymerized>isolated).\"\n          [16] \"The greater stability of the V(5) silica supported vanadia species may be directly related to the fact that only isolated surface vanadia species are present in this catalyst.\"\n          [17] \"The influence of preparation methods upon the molecular structure of the hydrated and dehydrated surface vanadia species has also been examined.\"\n          [18] \"The same thermodynamically stable surface metal oxide species are formed independent of the specific synthesis method.\"\n          [19] \"The influence of the specific structure or modification of the oxide support upon the molecular structure of the dehydrated surface vanadia species on well-defined TiO2 supports (anatase, rutile, brookite and B) was investigated with solid state 51V NMR and Raman spectroscopy.\"\n          [20] \"The same dehydrated surface vanadia species, already discussed above in Section 5.1.2, were found to be present on all the different TiO2 modifications suggesting that there is no effect of long range order of the oxide substrate upon the local structure of the surface vanadia species.\"\n          [21] \"The oxide supports only possess surface Lewis acid sites and the relative strength of these sites is A12Oa>Nb2Os>TiO2>ZrO2, and no surface Lewis acid sites are detected for SiO2.\"\n          [22] \"In contrast to the oxide supports, unsupported V205 crystalline powders possess both surface BrCnsted and surface Lewis acid sites.\"\n          [23] \"The formation of the surface vanadia species on the oxide supports is accompanied by a decrease in the number of surface Lewis acid sites and an increase in the number of surface Br0nsted acid sites.\"\n          [24] \"The exact location of the surface BrCnsted acid sites is not clear at present since solid state 1H NMR studies cannot clearly discriminate between different locations due to similar NMR peak positions.\"\n          [25] \"The acidic characteristics of the surface vanadia overlayer are influenced by the specific oxide support ligand, but the molecular structural characterization studies above (see Section 3) reveal that the same dehydrated surface vanadia species are present on all the oxide supports (with the exception of silica).\"\n          [26] \"The in situ characterization studies (Section 5.5) revealed that dehydrated surface vanadia species are present during hydrocarbon oxidation reactions and, consequently, the reactivity properties need to be related to the dehydrated surface vanadia species.\"\n          [27] \"The reactivity properties of the supported vanadia catalysts will be compared with the structural properties of the dehydrated surface V(5+) species rather than the dehydrated, reduced surface vanadia V(4+) and V(3+) species.\"\n          [28] \"The terminal V=O bonds have been proposed by many investigators to contain the critical oxygen involved in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions over supported vanadia catalysts [4].\"\n          [29] \"The available data suggests that the terminal V=O bonds do not contain the critical oxygen that affects the reactivity of supported vanadia catalysts during hydrocarbon oxidation reactions.\"\n          [30] \"The surface concentration of bridging V-O-V bonds increases with surface vanadia coverage due to the increase in the ratio of polymerized to isolated surface vanadia species with the exception of V205]SiO 2 (see Section 5.1 above).\"\n          [31] \"Although the bridging V-O-V bonds do not appear to significantly influence many of the oxidation reactions, more systematic studies with well-defined model supported vanadia catalysts are required to fully understand the role of bridging V-O-V bonds in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions.\"\n          [32] \"The bridging V-O-support bond appears to be associated with the critical oxygen required for hydrocarbon oxidation reactions since changing the specific oxide support dra- matically affects the TOF: approximately four orders of magnitude for methanol oxidation to formaldehyde [19] and two-orders of magnitude for butane oxidation to maleic anhydride [36].\"\n          [33] \"The general trend appears to be CeOz>ZrO2 TiO2>NbzOs>A12Os>SiO2, which inversely correlates with the Sanderson elec- tronegativity of the oxide support cations [97].\"\n          [34] \"This suggests that bridging oxygens in V-O-support bonds that are more electronegative or basic, corresponding to oxide support cations with a lower electronegativity,are associated with the critical oxygen required for hydrocarbon oxidation reactions over supported vanadia catalysts.\"\n          [35] \"In general, reactions requiring only one surface site will exhibit a TOF that is independent of surface vanadia coverage.\"\n          [36] \"The invariance of the TOF for methanol oxidation to formaldehyde with surface vanadia coverage over supported vanadia catalysts suggests that only one surface vanadia site is required for this reaction.\"\n          [37] \"The oxidation of methane to formaldehyde over V205/ SiO2 catalysts also exhibits a constant TOF with surface vanadia coverage suggesting that only one surface vanadia site is involved with this reaction, and is consistent with the isolated nature of the surface vanadia species on silica [35].\"\n          [38] \"An increase in the TOF with the surface vanadia coverage may reflect the requirement of multiple surface vanadia sites or the influence of other factors (e.g., surface acidity,influence of bridging V-O-V bonds, structural changes, etc.).\"\n          [39] \"Some of these other factors can be discriminated with the addition of metal oxide additives to the supported vanadia catalysts as discussed below.\"\n          [40] \"The addition of surface niobia is especially informative since it has a minimal effect on the surface vanadia structure, see Section 5.6 above, and its presence primarily increases the number of adjacent surface metal oxide sites for the surface vanadia species.\"\n          [41] \"The introduction of surface niobia species to V2Os/TiO2 catalysts increases the TOF for the oxidation of butane to maleic anhydride [36].\"\n          [42] \"This increase in TOF reflects the requirement of multiple surface metal oxide sites for this hydrocarbon oxidation reaction.\"\n          [43] \"Interacting additives and especially interacting basic surface oxides retard the reduction of surface vanadia species.\"\n          [44] \"Consequently, the TOFs for all hydrocarbon oxidation reactions are decreased when basic additives are intro- duced.\"\n          [45] \"The negative effect of the basic additives on the TOFs for methanol oxidation and propane oxidation over V2Os/TiO2 catalysts have been reported in the literature [59,99].\"\n          [46] \"In the case of V205/SIO2, the situation is even more drastic since the basic metal oxide additives also convert the two-dimensional surface vanadia species to three-dimensional crystalline mixed metal oxide phases [100].\"\n          [47] \"Interacting acidic additives such as P may have a different effect on various oxidation reactions.\"\n          [48] \"For methanol oxidation to formaldehyde, the presence of surface phosphate species slightly decreases the TOF [59].\"\n          [49] \"However, for butane oxidation to maleic anhydride the presence of surface phosphate species increases the TOF [36].\"\n          [50] \"The surface niobia species, a noninteracting additive possessing Lewis acidity [75], has no effect on the selectivity of formaldehyde during methanol oxidation [59], but does have a positive effect on the maleic anhydride selectivity during butane oxidation [36].\"\n          [51] \"The formaldehyde selectivity during methanol oxidation is slightly enhanced by the presence of basic interacting additives and decreased by the presence of acidic interacting additives [59].\"\n          [52] \"The propylene selectivity during propane oxidative dehydrogenation is enhanced by the presence of basic interacting additives [99].\"\n          [53] \"In contrast, the maleic anhydride selectivity during butane oxidation is enhanced by the presence of acidic interacting additives [36].\"\n          [54] \"It is tempting to conclude from this limited data that the selectivity of oxidative dehydrogenation reactions, oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde and propane to propylene, is enhanced by basic additives and that the selectivity of hydrogen abstraction-oxygen insertion reactions, butane oxidation to maleic anhydride, is enhanced by acidic additives.\"\n          [55] \"However, many more hydrocarbon oxidation reactions need to be examined before these observations can be general- ized.\"\n          [56] \"The specific phase of the oxide support as well as the specific preparation method do not appear to influence the molecular structure or reac- tivity of the surface vanadia species.\"\n          [57] \"The number of surface vanadia sites required for a hydrocarbon oxidation reaction is dependent on the specific reac- tant molecule.\"\n          [58] \"Oxidation reactions requiring only one surface vanadia sites are generally not sensitive to the surface vanadia coverage and the presence of noninteracting metal oxide additives.\"\n          [59] \"Oxidation reactions requiring multiple surface vanadia sites are very sensitive to surface vanadia coverage and the presence of noninteracting metal oxide additives.\"\n          [60] \"However, interacting additives influence all hydrocarbon oxidation reactions since they modify the surface vanadia sites.\"\n          [61] \"Acidic and basic additives also influence the selectivity of hydro- carbon oxidation reactions, but the effect appears to be reaction specific and cannot be generalized with the limited data currently available.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions. Supported vanadium oxide catalysts, which contain surface vanadia species on oxide supports, are widely used in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions. The structure and reactivity of these surface vanadia species are influenced by factors such as monolayer surface coverage, stability of the surface vanadia monolayer, oxidation state, molecular structures, acidity, and the specific oxide support phase. The stability of the surface vanadia monolayer on typical oxide supports ensures the long life of industrial oxidation catalysts. The molecular structures of the surface vanadia species have been extensively studied using various spectroscopic techniques. The molecular structures of the surface vanadia species are determined by the net pH of the aqueous thin film, which depends on the surface point of zero charge of the oxide support and the amount of the surface vanadia species. The hydration-dehydration processes of the supported vanadia catalysts are completely reversible. The reduction of surface vanadia species in reducing environments results in the formation of surface vanadia (4+) and vanadia (3+) species. The molecular structures of the reduced surface vanadia species can be determined using in situ EPR, UV-VIS DRS, and XANES/EXAFS measurements. The influence of hydrocarbon oxidation reaction environments on the oxidation states of the surface vanadia species in supported vanadia catalysts has been examined for several reactions using in situ Raman spectroscopy. The in situ Raman studies provide insights into the behavior of surface vanadia species during hydrocarbon oxidation reactions, including the predominant surface vanadia species, the extent of reduction, the specific oxide support, and the ratio of polymerized to isolated surface vanadia species. The stability of the V(5) silica supported vanadia species may be related to the presence of only isolated surface vanadia species in this catalyst. The influence of preparation methods on the molecular structure of the hydrated and dehydrated surface vanadia species has been examined, and the same thermodynamically stable surface metal oxide species are formed independent of the specific synthesis method. The influence of the specific structure or modification of the oxide support on the molecular structure of the dehydrated surface vanadia species has been investigated, and no effect of long range order of the oxide substrate on the local structure of the surface vanadia species was found. The oxide supports possess surface Lewis acid sites, while unsupported V205 crystalline powders possess both surface BrCnsted and surface Lewis acid sites. The formation of the surface vanadia species on the oxide supports is accompanied by a decrease in the number of surface Lewis acid sites and an increase in the number of surface Br0nsted acid sites. The exact location of the surface BrCnsted acid sites is unclear, and the acidic characteristics of the surface vanadia overlayer are influenced by the specific oxide support ligand. The reactivity properties of supported vanadia catalysts are related to the dehydrated surface vanadia species, and the reactivity properties will be compared with the structural properties of the dehydrated surface V(5+) species rather than the dehydrated, reduced surface vanadia V(4+) and V(3+) species. The terminal V=O bonds do not contain the critical oxygen that affects the reactivity of supported vanadia catalysts during hydrocarbon oxidation reactions. The surface concentration of bridging V-O-V bonds increases with surface vanadia coverage, and more systematic studies are required to fully understand the role of bridging V-O-V bonds in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions. The bridging V-O-support bond appears to be associated with the critical oxygen required for hydrocarbon oxidation reactions, and changing the specific oxide support dramatically affects the TOF. The general trend is inversely correlated with the Sanderson electronegativity of the oxide support cations, suggesting that bridging oxygens in V-O-support bonds that are more electronegative or basic are associated with the critical oxygen required for hydrocarbon oxidation reactions over supported vanadia catalysts. The number of surface vanadia sites required for a hydrocarbon oxidation reaction is dependent on the specific reactant molecule. Oxidation reactions requiring only one surface vanadia site exhibit a TOF that is independent of surface vanadia coverage, while oxidation reactions requiring multiple surface vanadia sites are sensitive to surface vanadia coverage and the presence of noninteracting metal oxide additives. Interacting additives influence all hydrocarbon oxidation reactions by modifying the surface vanadia sites. Acidic and basic additives also influence the selectivity of hydrocarbon oxidation reactions, but the effect appears to be reaction-specific and cannot be generalized with the limited data currently available. The unique physical and chemical characteristics of supported vanadia catalysts, compared to other supported metal oxide catalysts, contribute to their industrial significance in hydrocarbon oxidation reactions.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件，包括支持的钒氧化物和金属交换沸石，对烷烃转化的机制和效率有重大影响，特别是在氧化脱氢和沸石催化反应等过程中。支持的钒氧化物催化剂，含有在氧化物支持上的表面钒氧化物物种，被广泛用于烃类氧化反应。表面钒氧化物物种的结构和反应性受到单层表面覆盖、表面钒氧化物单层的稳定性、氧化态、分子结构、酸性以及特定氧化物支持相的影响。表面钒氧化物单层在典型的氧化物支持上的稳定性确保了工业氧化催化剂的长寿命。表面钒氧化物物种的分子结构已经通过各种光谱技术进行了广泛的研究。表面钒氧化物物种的分子结构由薄水膜的净pH决定，这取决于氧化物支持的表面零电荷点和表面钒氧化物物种的数量。支持的钒氧化物催化剂的水合-脱水过程是完全可逆的。在还原环境中，表面钒氧化物(5+)物种的还原导致表面钒氧化物(4+)和钒氧化物(3+)物种的形成。表面钒氧化物物种的还原分子结构可以通过原位EPR、UV-VIS DRS和XANES/EXAFS测量来确定。对支持的钒氧化物催化剂中表面钒氧化物物种的氧化态的烃类氧化反应环境的影响已经通过原位拉曼光谱对几种反应进行了检查。原位拉曼研究提供了关于表面钒氧化物物种在烃类氧化反应中的行为的见解，包括主要的表面钒氧化物物种、还原程度、特定的氧化物支持以及聚合表面钒氧化物物种与孤立表面钒氧化物物种的比例。V(5)硅支持的钒氧化物物种的稳定性可能与这种催化剂中只存在孤立表面钒氧化物物种有关。已经检查了制备方法对水合和脱水表面钒氧化物物种的分子结构的影响，无论具体的合成方法如何，都会形成相同的热力学稳定的表面金属氧化物物种。已经研究了特定结构或氧化物支持的修改对脱水表面钒氧化物物种的分子结构的影响，没有发现氧化物基质的长程秩序对表面钒氧化物物种的局部结构有影响。氧化物支持只具有表面路易斯酸位，而未受支持的V205结晶粉末同时具有表面布龙斯特和表面路易斯酸位。在氧化物支持上形成表面钒氧化物物种伴随着表面路易斯酸位数量的减少和表面布龙斯特酸位数量的增加。表面布龙斯特酸位的确切位置尚不清楚，表面钒氧化物覆盖层的酸性特征受到特定氧化物支持配体的影响。支持的钒氧化物催化剂的反应性性质与脱水表面钒氧化物物种有关，反应性性质将与脱水表面V(5+)物种的结构性质进行比较，而不是脱水、还原表面钒氧化物V(4+)和V(3+)物种。终端V=O键不含影响支持的钒氧化物催化剂在烃类氧化反应中的反应性的关键氧。表面V-O-V键的浓度随着表面钒氧化物覆盖度的增加而增加，需要更系统的研究来充分理解表面V-O-V键在烃类氧化反应中的作用。V-O-支持键似乎与烃类氧化反应所需的临界氧有关，改变特定的氧化物支持会极大地影响TOF。一般趋势与氧化物支持阳离子的桑德森电负性成反比，表明V-O-支持键中更电负或更碱性的氧与支持的钒氧化物催化剂上的烃类氧化反应所需的临界氧有关。对于烃类氧化反应所需的表面钒氧化物位点的数量取决于特定的反应物分子。只需要一个表面钒氧化物位点的氧化反应的TOF与表面钒氧化物覆盖度无关，而需要多个表面钒氧化物位点的氧化反应对表面钒氧化物覆盖度和非相互作用金属氧化物添加剂的存在非常敏感。相互作用的添加剂通过改变表面钒氧化物位点影响所有烃类氧化反应。酸性和碱性添加剂也影响烃类氧化反应的选择性，但影响似乎是反应特异性的，不能用目前有限的数据进行概括。与其它支持的金属氧化物催化剂相比，支持的钒氧化物催化剂的独特物理和化学特性，对烃类氧化反应的工业重要性有贡献。", "Doi": "10.1016/s0926-860x(97)00021-5"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. In processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions, the nature of the active sites, the acidity, and the pore structure of the catalysts play crucial roles. The industrial significance of these catalysts is attributed to their ability to activate and transform light alkanes into more valuable products, such as aromatics and isomers, under mild conditions. The efficiency of these transformations is enhanced by optimizing the catalyst composition and reaction conditions, which can lead to higher yields and selectivities. Moreover, the development of novel regeneration methods for these catalysts can help to mitigate deactivation and extend their operational life, further enhancing their industrial application.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件，包括支撑的钒氧化物和金属交换沸石，对烷烃转化的机理和效率有重大影响。在氧化脱氢和沸石催化反应等过程中，活性位点的性质、催化剂的酸性和孔结构起着关键作用。这些催化剂的工业重要性在于它们能够在温和条件下激活和转化轻烷烃为更有价值的产品，如芳烃和异构体。通过优化催化剂组成和反应条件，可以提高这些转化的效率，从而导致更高的产率和选择性。此外，新型催化剂再生方法的开发可以帮助缓解失活，延长其使用寿命，进一步增强其工业应用。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.molcata.2006.03.068"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The catalytic properties of Al2O3-supported vanadia with a wide range of VOx surface density (1.434.2 V/nm2) and structure were examined for the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane and propane.\"\n          [2] \"Propene formation rates (per V atom) are approximately eight times higher than ethene formation rates at a given reaction temperature, but the apparent ODH activation energies (E1) are similar for the two reactants and relatively insensitive to vanadia surface density.\"\n          [3] \"The ratio of k2/k1 is independent of surface density for ethane but increases slightly with vanadia surface density for propane, suggesting that isolated structures prevalent at low surface densities are slightly more selective for alkane dehydrogenation reactions.\"\n          [4] \"The ratio of k3/k1 decreases markedly with increasing reaction temperature for both ethane and propane ODH.\"\n          [5] \"The highest yield of alkene is obtained for catalysts containing predominantly isolated monovanadate species and operated at high temperatures that avoid homogeneous reactions (<800 K).\"\n          [6] \"The effects of oxide domain size and of support on rates and selectivity have been attributed to the acidbase properties of the VOx and support surfaces.\"\n          [7] \"The effects of VOx surface density and structure on rates and selectivities for ethane and propane ODH reactions have been previously reported (718), with somewhat inconsistent results.\"\n          [8] \"The lack of detailed structural characterization and rigorous kinetic analysis of integral (high conversion) rate and selectivity data, and the temperature gradients and possible homogeneous reactions prevalent at the high temperatures and conversions of many previous studies, have contributed to the persistent controversies.\"\n          [9] \"Here, we report a detailed kinetic analysis of ethane ODH reactions on VOx/Al2O3 samples with a wide range of VOx surface densities (1.434 VOx/nm2) and contrast the results with those obtained using propane as the reactant.\"\n          [10] \"We have combined this analysis with detailed structural characterization of these catalysts in order to relate their local structure to the values of the rate constants,which characterize the function of these catalytic materials.\"\n          [11] \"In addition, we contrast the reaction rates of ethane and propane molecules with different CH bond energies and different adsorption energies of the respective alkenes.\"\n          [12] \"As surface densities increase, two-dimensional poly-vanadates appear (2.37.0 V/nm2), along with increasing amounts of V2O5 crystallites at surface densities above 7.0 V/nm2.\"\n          [13] \"Ethene and propene formation rates (per V atom) are strongly influenced by vanadia surface density and reach a maximum value at intermediate surface densities (8 V/nm2).\"\n          [14] \"The effects of oxide domain size and of support on rates and selectivity have been attributed to the acidbase properties of the VOx and support surfaces.\"\n          [15] \"The local structure of supported VOx domains strongly influences ODH reaction rates and selectivity.\"\n          [16] \"High alkene yields at reasonable residence times require high values of k1 and low values of k2/k1 and k3/k1.\"\n          [17] \"The effects of VOx surface density and structure on rates and selectivities for ethane and propane ODH reactions have been previously reported (718), with somewhat inconsistent results.\"\n          [18] \"The lack prevalent at the high temperatures and conversions of many previous studies, have contributed to the persistent controversies.\"\n          [19] \"The spectroscopic results presented in Figs. 1 and 2 suggest that distorted tetrahedral monovanadate structures connected to the support via VOAl bonds are prevalent at low surface densities.\"\n          [20] \"As V surface densities increase, two-dimensional polyvanadates form via reactions leading to VOV bonds connecting neighboring VOx species.\"\n          [21] \"VOx species exceeding monolayer coverages react with polyvanadates structures to form three-dimensional structures that ultimately crystallize into bulk V2O5, with some evidence for residual monovanadate species.\"\n          [22] \"The rate per V atom increases with surface densities, even though V atoms become increasingly unavailable for catalysis as three-dimensional structures form.\"\n          [23] \"The constant areal rate obtained after completion of a polyvanadate monolayer suggests that the surface reactivity of VOx species becomes independent of domain size once the predominant structures involve VOV bonds.\"\n          [24] \"The sample with the lowest vanadia surface density (1.4 V/nm2) and containing predominately monovanadates shows the highest initial alkene selectivity for both ethane and propane ODH.\"\n          [25] \"The ratio of k2/k1 is independent of surface density for ethane and increases with increasing vanadia surface density for propane (Fig. 8).\"\n          [26] \"The ratio of k3/k1 increases with increasing vanadia with increasing vanadia surface density for propane ODH.\"\n          [30] \"However, k3/k1 is generally higher for propane than for ethane ODH, indicating that the propene is more reactive relative to propane than ethene is to ethane.\"\n          [31] \"The activation energies for ethane and propane ODH, E1, and ethane and propane combustion, E2, are similar in magnitude at 115  20 kJ/mol and show weak dependence on vanadia surface density.\"\n          [32] \"The propene formation rate is approximately eight times larger than the ethene formation rate at 663 K, suggesting that that the stabilization energy for ethoxide species may be higher relative to isopropoxide in the activated state.\"\n          [33] \"The apparent activation energy for alkene combustion, E3, is 6090 kJ/mol and increases with vanadia surface density, leading to a decrease in E13 with increasing vanadia surface density.\"\n          [34] \"The trends in E3 and E13 appear to be caused by decreasingly exothermic alkene adsorption as vanadia surface density increases.\"\n          [35] \"Alkene selectivity generally increases with increasing reaction temperature and with decreasing vanadia surface density.\"\n          [36] \"Therefore, the highest olefin yields are obtained on catalysts containing isolated monovanadates and operated at the highest possible reaction temperature consistent with the avoidance of homogeneous reactions.\"\n          [37] \"As surface densities increase, two-dimensional poly-vanadates appear (2.37.0 V/nm2), along with increasing amounts of V2O5 crystallites at surface densities (8 V/nm2).\"\n          [39] \"The highest yield of alkene is obtained for catalysts containing predominantly isolated monovanadate species and operated at high temperatures that avoid homogeneous reactions (<800 K).\"\n          [40] \"The effects of oxide domain size and of support on rates and selectivity have been attributed to the acidbase properties of the VOx and support surfaces.\"\n          [41] \"The local structure of supported VOx domains strongly influences ODH reaction rates and selectivity.\"\n          [42] \"High alkene yields at reasonable residence times require high values of k1 and low values of k2/k1 and k3/k1.\"\n          [43] \"The effects of VOx surface density and structure on rates and selectivities for ethane and propane ODH reactions have been previously reported (718), with somewhat inconsistent results.\"\n          [44] \"The lack of detailed structural characterization and rigorous kinetic analysis of integral (high conversion) rate and selectivity data, and the temperature gradients and possible homogeneous reactions prevalent at the high temperatures and conversions of many previous studies, have contributed to the persistent controversies.\"\n          [45] \"Here, we report a detailed kinetic analysis of ethane ODH reactions on VOx/Al2O3 samples with a wide range of VOx surface densities (1.434 VOx/nm2) and contrast the results with those obtained using propane as the reactant.\"\n          [46] \"We have combined this analysis with detailed structural characterization of these catalysts in order to relate their local structure to the values of the rate constants,which characterize the function of these catalytic materials.\"\n          [47] \"In addition, we contrast the reaction rates of ethane and propane molecules with different CH bond energies and different adsorption energies of the respective alkenes.\"", "English": "The catalytic properties of alumina-supported vanadia with a wide range of vanadia surface densities and structures were examined for the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane and propane. Propene formation rates are about eight times higher than ethene formation rates at a given reaction temperature, but the apparent activation energies for oxidative dehydrogenation are similar for both reactants and relatively insensitive to vanadia surface density. The ratio of the rate constant for alkane combustion to the rate constant for oxidative dehydrogenation is independent of surface density for ethane but increases slightly with vanadia surface density for propane. The ratio of the rate constant for alkene combustion to the rate constant for oxidative dehydrogenation decreases markedly with increasing reaction temperature for both ethane and propane oxidative dehydrogenation. The highest yield of alkene is obtained for catalysts containing predominantly isolated monovanadate species and operated at high temperatures that avoid homogeneous reactions. The effects of oxide domain size and support on rates and selectivity have been attributed to the acid-base properties of the vanadia and support surfaces. Previous studies on the effects of vanadia surface density and structure on rates and selectivities for ethane and propane oxidative dehydrogenation have yielded inconsistent results. The lack of detailed structural characterization and rigorous kinetic analysis, as well as the temperature gradients and possible homogeneous reactions prevalent at high temperatures and conversions in many previous studies, have contributed to the persistent controversies. A detailed kinetic analysis of ethane oxidative dehydrogenation reactions on vanadia/alumina samples with a wide range of vanadia surface densities was reported, contrasting the results with those obtained using propane as the reactant. This analysis was combined with detailed structural characterization of the catalysts to relate their local structure to the values of the rate constants that characterize the function of these catalytic materials. The reaction rates of ethane and propane molecules with different CH bond energies and different adsorption energies of the respective alkenes were also contrasted. As the surface density increases, two-dimensional poly-vanadates appear, along with increasing amounts of V2O5 crystallites. Ethene and propene formation rates per vanadium atom are strongly influenced by vanadia surface density, reaching a maximum at intermediate surface densities. The highest yield of alkene is obtained for catalysts containing predominantly isolated monovanadate species and operated at high temperatures that avoid homogeneous reactions. The effects of oxide domain size and support on rates and selectivity have been attributed to the acid-base properties of the vanadia and support surfaces. The local structure of supported vanadia domains strongly influences oxidative dehydrogenation reaction rates and selectivity. High alkene yields at reasonable residence times require high values of k1 and low values of k2/k1 and k3/k1. The effects of vanadia surface density and structure on ethane and propane oxidative dehydrogenation rates and selectivities have been previously reported with inconsistent results. The lack of detailed structural characterization and rigorous kinetic analysis, as well as the temperature gradients and possible homogeneous reactions at high temperatures and conversions in many previous studies, have contributed to ongoing controversies. The spectroscopic results suggest that distorted tetrahedral monovanadate structures connected to the support via VOAl bonds are prevalent at low surface densities. As V surface densities increase, two-dimensional polyvanadates form via reactions leading to VOV bonds connecting neighboring VOx species. VOx species exceeding monolayer coverages react with polyvanadates structures to form three-dimensional structures that ultimately crystallize into bulk V2O5, with some evidence for residual monovanadate species. The rate per V atom increases with surface densities, even though V atoms become increasingly unavailable for catalysis as three-dimensional structures form. The constant areal rate obtained after completion of a polyvanadate monolayer suggests that the surface reactivity of VOx species becomes independent of domain size once the predominant structures involve VOV bonds. The sample with the lowest vanadia surface density and containing predominately monovanadates shows the highest initial alkene selectivity for both ethane and propane ODH. The ratio of k2/k1 is independent of surface density for ethane and increases with increasing vanadia surface density for propane. The ratio of k3/k1 increases with increasing vanadia surface density for both reactants. Smaller values of k3/k1 and k2/k1 lead to higher alkene selectivity at all reactant conversion levels. The ratio of k2/k1 is relatively independent of both reaction temperature and vanadia surface density for ethane ODH. The ratio of k2/k1 is independent of reaction temperature, but increases with increasing vanadia surface density for propane ODH. However, k3/k1 is generally higher for propane than for ethane ODH, indicating that the propene is more reactive relative to propane than ethene is to ethane. The activation energies for ethane and propane ODH, E1, and ethane and propane combustion, E2, are similar in magnitude at 115  20 kJ/mol and show weak dependence on vanadia surface density. The propene formation rate is approximately eight times larger than the ethene formation rate at 663 K, suggesting that that the stabilization energy for ethoxide species may be higher relative to isopropoxide in the activated state. The apparent activation energy for alkene combustion, E3, is 6090 kJ/mol and increases with vanadia surface density, leading to a decrease in E13 with increasing vanadia surface density. The trends in E3 and E13 appear to be caused by decreasingly exothermic alkene adsorption as vanadia surface density increases. Alkene selectivity generally increases with increasing reaction temperature and with decreasing vanadia surface density. Therefore, the highest olefin yields are obtained on catalysts containing isolated monovanadates and operated at the highest possible reaction temperature consistent with the avoidance of homogeneous reactions. As surface densities increase, two-dimensional poly-vanadates appear, along with increasing amounts of V2O5 crystallites. Ethene and propene formation rates (per V atom) are strongly influenced by vanadia surface density and reach a maximum value at intermediate surface densities. The highest yield of alkene is obtained for catalysts containing predominantly isolated monovanadate species and operated at high temperatures that avoid homogeneous reactions. The effects of oxide domain size and of support on rates and selectivity have been attributed to the acidbase properties of the VOx and support surfaces. The local structure of supported VOx domains strongly influences ODH reaction rates and selectivity. High alkene yields at reasonable residence times require high values of k1 and low values of k2/k1 and k3/k1. The effects of VOx surface density and structure on rates and selectivities for ethane and propane ODH reactions have been previously reported, with somewhat inconsistent results. The lack of detailed structural characterization and rigorous kinetic analysis of integral (high conversion) rate and selectivity data, and the temperature gradients and possible homogeneous reactions prevalent at the high temperatures and conversions of many previous studies, have contributed to the persistent controversies. A detailed kinetic analysis of ethane ODH reactions on VOx/Al2O3 samples with a wide range of VOx surface densities was reported and contrasted with those obtained using propane as the reactant. This analysis was combined with detailed structural characterization of these catalysts in order to relate their local structure to the values of the rate constants. In addition, the reaction rates of ethane and propane molecules with different CH bond energies and different adsorption energies of the respective alkenes were contrasted.", "Chinese": "研究了具有广泛范氧化物表面密度和结构的氧化铝支撑的范氧化物的催化性能，用于乙烷和丙烷的氧化脱氢。在给定的反应温度下，丙烯形成速率大约是乙烯形成速率的八倍，但氧化脱氢的表观活化能对于两种反应物是相似的，对范氧化物表面密度相对不敏感。乙烷的烷烃燃烧速率常数与氧化脱氢速率常数之比与表面密度无关，但丙烷的该比值随范氧化物表面密度略有增加。对于乙烷和丙烷氧化脱氢，烷烃燃烧速率常数与氧化脱氢速率常数之比随反应温度显著下降。在避免均相反应的高温下操作，主要含有孤立的单范酸盐物种的催化剂可以获得最高的烯烃产率。氧化物域尺寸和支撑对速率和选择性的影响归因于范氧化物和支撑表面的酸碱性质。关于范氧化物表面密度和结构对乙烷和丙烷氧化脱氢速率和选择性影响的先前研究结果不一致。许多先前研究中缺乏详细的结构表征和严格的动力学分析，以及高温和高转化率下常见的温度梯度和可能的均相反应，导致了持续的争议。报告了对具有广泛范氧化物表面密度的范氧化物/氧化铝样品的乙烷氧化脱氢反应的详细动力学分析，对比了使用丙烷作为反应物得到的结果。该分析与催化剂的详细结构表征相结合，以将它们的局部结构与表征这些催化材料功能的速率常数值相关联。还对比了具有不同CH键能和各自烯烃不同吸附能的乙烷和丙烷分子的反应速率。随着表面密度的增加，二维多范酸盐出现，伴随着V2O5晶体的增加。每单位钒原子的乙烯和丙烯形成速率受范氧化物表面密度的强烈影响，在中间表面密度时达到最大值。在主要包含孤立的单范酸盐物种并在避免均相反应的高温下操作的催化剂中，可以获得最高的烯烃产量。氧化物域尺寸和支撑对速率和选择性的影响归因于范氧化物和支撑表面的酸碱性质。支撑的范氧化物域的局部结构强烈影响氧化脱氢反应速率和选择性。在合理的停留时间内获得高烯烃产量需要k1的高值和k2/k1和k3/k1的低值。关于范氧化物表面密度和结构对乙烷和丙烷氧化脱氢速率和选择性的影响，以前的研究报告了不一致的结果。许多以前的研究中缺乏详细的结构表征和严格的动力学分析，以及高温和转化率下的温度梯度和可能的均相反应，导致了持续的争议。光谱学结果表明，通过VOAl键与支撑连接的扭曲四面体单钒酸盐结构在低表面密度下普遍存在。随着V表面密度的增加，通过导致VOx物种之间VOV键的反应形成二维多钒酸盐。超过单层覆盖的VOx物种与多钒酸盐结构反应，形成最终结晶成块体V2O5的三维结构，有证据表明存在残留的单钒酸盐物种。V原子的速率随表面密度的增加而增加，即使V原子随着三维结构的形成而变得越来越不可用于催化。在完成多钒酸盐单层后获得的恒定面积速率表明，一旦主要结构涉及VOV键，VOx物种的表面反应性就变得独立于域尺寸。表面钒密度最低且主要含有单钒酸盐的样品对乙烷和丙烷ODH都显示出最高的初始烯烃选择性。k2/k1的比率对于乙烷是独立于表面密度的，而对于丙烷，它随着钒表面密度的增加而增加。k3/k1的比率对于两种反应物都随着钒表面密度的增加而增加。k3/k1和k2/k1的较小值导致所有反应物转化水平的烯烃选择性更高。k2/k1的比率对于乙烷ODH在反应温度和钒表面密度方面都是相对独立的。k2/k1的比率独立于反应温度，但随着丙烷ODH的钒表面密度的增加而增加。然而，k3/k1通常对于丙烷比对于乙烷ODH更高，表明丙烯相对于丙烷比乙烯相对于乙烷更具有反应性。乙烷和丙烷ODH以及乙烷和丙烷燃烧的活化能E1和E2的大小相似，在115  20 kJ/mol左右，对钒表面密度的依赖性较弱。在663 K时，丙烯形成速率大约是乙烯形成速率的八倍，这表明在活化状态下，乙氧基物种的稳定化能可能相对于异丙氧基更高。烯烃燃烧的表观活化能E3为6090 kJ/mol，并且随着钒表面密度的增加而增加，导致E13随着钒表面密度的增加而减少。E3和E13的趋势似乎是由于随着钒表面密度的增加，烯烃吸附变得越来越放热引起的。烯烃选择性通常随着反应温度的升高和钒表面密度的降低而增加。因此，在避免均相反应的最高可能反应温度下操作，主要含有孤立单钒酸盐的催化剂可以获得最高的烯烃产量。随着表面密度的增加，二维多范酸盐出现，伴随着V2O5晶体的增加。每V原子的乙烯和丙烯生成速率受范氧化物表面密度的强烈影响，在中间表面密度时达到最大值。在主要包含孤立的单范酸盐物种并在避免均相反应的高温下操作的催化剂中，可以获得最高的烯烃产量。氧化物域尺寸和支撑对速率和选择性的影响归因于范氧化物和支撑表面的酸碱性质。支撑的范氧化物域的局部结构强烈影响ODH反应速率和选择性。在合理的停留时间内获得高烯烃产量需要k1的高值和k2/k1和k3/k1的低值。关于范氧化物表面密度和结构对乙烷和丙烷氧化脱氢速率和选择性的影响，以前的报道有些不一致。由于缺乏详细的结构表征和对积分(高转化率)速率和选择性数据的严格动力学分析，以及在许多先前研究的高温和高转化率下普遍存在的温度梯度和可能的均相反应，导致了持续的争议。报告了对具有广泛VOx表面密度(1.434 VOx/nm2)的VOx/Al2O3样品的乙烷ODH反应的详细动力学分析，与使用丙烷作为反应物的结果进行了对比。这种分析与这些催化剂的详细结构表征相结合，以将它们的局部结构与表征这些催化材料功能的速率常数的值联系起来。此外，对比了具有不同CH键能和不同吸附能的乙烷和丙烷分子的反应速率。", "Doi": "10.1006/jcat.2002.3570"},
{"Quotes": "\"Catalytic reactions of hydrocarbons in zeolites can be profoundly affected by extraframework transition-metal cationic clusters. MFI zeolites containing dehydrogenating species such as gallium, zinc, and platinum form the basis for light alkane aromatization (Cyclar, Aroforming, Z-forming) processes.\"\n          \"An additional appealing example is the incorporation of methane into gasoline products in the MTG process over Ga/HZSM-5.\"\n          \"A catalytic issue relates to the nature of the cationic clusters. Are the alkanes activated by isolated cations, or do the extraframework oxygen atoms also play a role?\"\n          \"The experimentally observed increase in activity of Ga+ species in ZSM-5 upon oxidation at 473K by nitrous oxide was ascribed to formation of gallyl (GaO+) ions.\"\n          \"According to this reaction scheme, GaO+ can be stabilized by addition of steam.\"\n          \"The increased dehydrogenation activity of Ga/ZSM-5 compared to HZSM-5 is obvious from the increased amount of hydrogen formed.\"\n          \"The promoting effect of water is due to the formation of reactive partly hydrolyzed gallium species.\"\n          \"Coordination of the hydroxyl group of the [Ga(H)(OH)]+ ion to the neighboring gallium cation results in a significant decrease of the reaction energy for H2 recombination (147kJmol1) compared to that from the isolated [Ga(H)(OH)]+ ion (242kJmol1).\"\n          \"The increased acidity of the bridging hydroxyl bond and the stable tetrahedral configuration around Ga3+ ions facilitate H2 desorption.\"\n          \"Dehydrogenation of an alkane over the Ga2O2 dimer proceeds by initial heterolytic dissociation by the Lewis acid pair formed by Ga3+ and the basic extraframework oxygen atom (Scheme1) with subsequent olefin desorption and hydrogen recombination.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, such as gallium, zinc, and platinum in MFI zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. These catalysts are crucial for processes like light alkane aromatization and the incorporation of methane into gasoline products. The nature of the cationic clusters, whether isolated cations or involving extraframework oxygen atoms, plays a key role in alkane activation. Oxidation of Ga+ species in ZSM-5 by nitrous oxide leads to the formation of gallyl (GaO+) ions, which are more reactive. The addition of steam stabilizes GaO+ ions, enhancing the dehydrogenation activity of Ga/ZSM-5 compared to HZSM-5. Water promotes the formation of reactive hydrolyzed gallium species, decreasing the reaction energy for hydrogen recombination. The stable tetrahedral configuration around Ga3+ ions facilitates hydrogen desorption. Alkane dehydrogenation over the Ga2O2 dimer involves heterolytic dissociation by the Lewis acid pair formed by Ga3+ and the basic extraframework oxygen atom, followed by olefin desorption and hydrogen recombination.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件,如MFI沸石中的镓、锌和铂,对烷烃转化的机制和效率有重大影响。这些催化剂对轻烷烃芳构化和甲烷转化为汽油产品等过程至关重要。催化团簇的性质,无论是孤立的阳离子还是涉及框架外氧原子,在烷烃活化中起着关键作用。ZSM-5中Ga+物种通过一氧化二氮氧化形成更活性的gallyl (GaO+)离子。添加蒸汽稳定了GaO+离子,增强了Ga/ZSM-5相对于HZSM-5的脱氢活性。水促进了反应性部分水解的镓物种的形成,降低了氢重组的能量。Ga3+离子周围稳定的四面体构型促进了氢的解吸。在Ga2O2二聚体上烷烃脱氢涉及由Ga3+和框架外碱性氧原子形成的路易斯酸对的异裂解离,随后是烯烃解吸和氢重组。", "Doi": "10.1002/anie.200702463"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The catalytic behavior of the V-P- based catalysts depends on the following main factors: Method of preparation of the precursor (type of reagents, reducing agents, and solvent; temperature, and dry or wet milling); P/V ratio; Presence of additives; and Methodology of activation and conditioning of the precursor at high temperature.\"\n          [2] \"The many different factors involved in the chemistry of preparation of the active phase can account for the differences and the lack of reproducibility of the data reported in the literature for this catalytic system.\"\n          [3] \"The necessary mechanical strength has been developed by (1) special treatment of the catalyst and addition of a small amount of promoters,8 (2) embedding the precursor with Z r and Ti pyrophosphate' in fluid-bed technologies, or (3) encapsulating the precursor in a shell of silica in moving-bed technology.\"\n          [4] \"The optimum precursor is the phase with 0.5 mol of water of crystallization?\"\n          [5] \"The main difference ob- served in several precursors is the morphology of the (VO) HP04.0.5H20 crystallites.\"\n          [6] \"The type of aliphatic alcohol influences the temperature of reduction of V 5+ which is kinetically controlled and complete only when benzyl alcohol (which forms benzaldehyde and benzoic acid) is utilized, when a long reduction time is used, and when the phosphoric acid is added.\"\n          [7] \"In summary, the effect of several parameters on the properties of (VO)HP04.0.5H20 is to vary the exposure of the (001) plane, create strain in the crystallite, and influence the extent of reduction of V5+.\"\n          [8] \"The localization of this excess phosphorus in the precursor has not yet been clarified.\"\n          [9] \"Different types of VOPO,, some of which can be reversibly reduced to (VO),P207,have been the 6 and aIr,2027 the y-25 and the 6*-19 VOPO.\"\n          [10] \"The P/V ratio. P/V ratios in the precursor higher than the stoichiometric amount stabilize (VO)P207 not only in the reactants atmosphere but also for calcination in a i r at high temperature.\"\n          [11] \"Minimization of impurities. and in air.\"", "English": "The catalytic behavior of V-P-based catalysts is influenced by the method of preparation of the precursor, the P/V ratio, the presence of additives, and the methodology of activation and conditioning at high temperatures. The preparation method affects the morphology of the (VO)HP04.0.5H20 crystallites, the exposure of the (001) plane, and the extent of reduction of V5+. The P/V ratio in the precursor stabilizes (VO)P207, and the morphology of the catalyst influences its oxidizability. Low-temperature treatment in an oxygen-containing atmosphere and the presence of certain additives can also affect the catalyst's performance. The conditioning of the catalyst can lead to a transformation of the surface from a situation where pyrophosphate groups predominate to one where orthophosphate groups predominate. A slight excess of phosphorus in the catalyst composition helps to avoid the oxidation of V4+. Catalysts with a slight excess of phosphorus exhibit a balance between reducibility and reoxidizability, which is necessary for high activity and selectivity. The industrial significance of these catalysts is due to their ability to selectively activate paraffins with high selectivity, which is crucial for processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions.", "Chinese": "V-P基催化剂的催化行为受前体制备方法、P/V比、添加剂的存在以及在高温下激活和条件化前体的方法的影响。制备方法影响(VO)HP04.0.5H20晶体的形态、(001)面的暴露程度以及V5+还原的程度。前体中的P/V比稳定(VO)P207，催化剂的形态影响其氧化性。在含氧气氛中低温处理以及某些添加剂的存在也会影响催化剂的性能。催化剂的条件化会导致表面从以焦磷酸基团为主的情况转变为以正磷酸基团为主的情况。催化剂组成中磷的轻微过量有助于避免V4+的氧化。具有轻微过量磷的催化剂在还原性和再氧化性之间表现出平衡，这对于高活性和选择性是必要的。这些催化剂的工业重要性在于它们能够以高选择性选择性地激活石蜡，这对于氧化脱氢和沸石催化反应等过程至关重要。", "Doi": "10.1039/9781847553232-00246"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"Two Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst series have been tested in the partial oxidation of methane to formaldehyde at atmospheric pres- sure.\"\n          [2] \"Conventional aqueous impregnation with ammonium heptamolybdate was used for preparing catalysts with Mo loading ranging from 0.3 to 3.3 wt.%. Two different molybdenum species were detected in these catalysts: tetrahedral monomeric Mo(VI) species and octahedral coordinated polymolybdate species.\"\n          [3] \"For molybdenum loading higher than 1.3 wt.%, polymolybdate species are predominant causing a decrease in the dispersion and a partial blocking up of the HZSM-5 zeolite channels.\"\n          [4] \"A second catalyst series were prepared from HZSM-5 zeolite by aqueous impregnation and subsequent washing with an aqueous ammonia solution, yielding Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts with Mo contents ranging from 0.08 to 0.45 wt.%. A well-dispersed molybdenum oxide phase mainly constituted of tetrahedral monomeric species joined to the zeolite surface was characterized.\"\n          [5] \"Both catalyst series show different activity in methane conversion. Polymolybdate species of impregnated Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts are more reactive in methane activation than acid sites of HZSM-5 but lead to low HCOH selectivity values.\"\n          [6] \"In contrast, treated catalysts show lower methane conversion but higher HCOH selectivity. These results demonstrate the specificity of the Mo=O sites of monomeric species for HCOH production.\"", "English": "The composition and structure of metal-based catalysts, such as Mo/HZSM-5, influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations. Two series of Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts were tested in the partial oxidation of methane to formaldehyde. The first series was prepared by conventional aqueous impregnation with ammonium heptamolybdate, resulting in two molybdenum species: tetrahedral monomeric Mo(VI) species and octahedral coordinated polymolybdate species. For molybdenum loading higher than 1.3 wt.%, polymolybdate species are predominant, causing a decrease in dispersion and partial blocking of the HZSM-5 zeolite channels. The second series was prepared by aqueous impregnation and subsequent washing with an aqueous ammonia solution, yielding a well-dispersed molybdenum oxide phase mainly constituted of tetrahedral monomeric species. The two catalyst series show different activity in methane conversion. Polymolybdate species are more reactive in methane activation but lead to low formaldehyde selectivity values. In contrast, treated catalysts show lower methane conversion but higher formaldehyde selectivity, demonstrating the specificity of the Mo=O sites of monomeric species for formaldehyde production.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成和结构,如Mo/HZSM-5,影响烷烃转化的机制和效率。测试了两系列Mo/HZSM-5催化剂在甲烷部分氧化为甲醛中的应用。第一系列通过常规的七钼酸铵水溶液浸渍制备,产生了两种钼物种:四面体单体Mo(VI)物种和八面体配位多钼酸盐物种。当钼负载高于1.3 wt.%时,多钼酸盐物种占主导,导致分散度下降和HZSM-5沸石通道的部分堵塞。第二系列通过水溶液浸渍和随后的氨水溶液洗涤制备,产生主要由四面体单体物种组成的钼氧化物分散相。两种催化剂系列在甲烷转化中的活性不同。多钼酸盐物种在甲烷活化中更反应性,但导致低甲醛选择性值。相比之下,处理后的催化剂显示较低的甲烷转化率,但较高的甲醛选择性,证明了单体物种的Mo=O位点对甲醛生产的特异性。", "Doi": "10.1016/s0926-860x(00)00472-5"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The literature does not provide specific information on how the composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions. However, it does discuss the use of zeolites as catalysts for selective oxidation reactions, particularly the oxidative hydroxylation of aromatics using dinitrogen monoxide. The best results were obtained for the oxidation of benzene to phenol over Fe-containing ZSM-5 zeolites, which proceeds with nearly 100% selectivity at 25-30% benzene conversion. The efficiency of these catalysts is influenced by the nature of catalytic activity of zeolites, the role of iron, the chemical composition of the zeolite matrix, and the specific features of dinitrogen monoxide as an oxidant. Further progress in this promising direction, the hydroxylation of aromatics, can provide new efficient technologies in organic synthesis.", "Chinese": "文献没有提供具体信息关于金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件如何影响烷烃转化机制和效率。但是，它确实讨论了使用沸石作为催化剂进行选择性氧化反应，特别是使用一氧化二氮进行芳烃的氧化羟基化。在Fe-ZSM-5沸石催化下，苯氧化为酚的最佳结果是，在25-30%的苯转化率下，几乎达到100%的选择性。这些催化剂的效率受到沸石催化活性的本质、铁的作用、沸石基质的化学组成以及一氧化二氮作为氧化剂的特殊性质的影响。在这一有前景的方向上，即芳烃的羟基化，进一步的进展可以为有机合成提供新的高效技术。", "Doi": "10.1016/0926-860x(93)85021-g"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The catalytic dehydrocondensation of methane to benzene and naphthalene with a bulky of hydrogen on transition metal supported zeolite catalysts is one of strategies for the catalytic conversion of methane and a challenging topic in heterogeneous catalysis.\"\n          [2] \"The results of investigation on the carbonaceous deposits and the synergetic effect between the transition metal components and the zeolite supports, as well as, the active species and reaction mechanisms are revealed by the TPO/XPS/FT-IR/EXAFS and solid NMR studies.\"\n          [3] \"Many processes related with methane conversion,whether direct or indirect route, require the use of oxygen, so the deep oxidation of methane is unavoidable.\"\n          [4] \"In order to suppress the formation of undesirable products such as CO and CO2, many researchers tried to transform methane into higher hydrocarbons in the absence of oxygen.\"\n          [5] \"It is generally accepted that the Mo/HZSM-5 is one of the good catalysts as reported by groups of Xu and co-workers [13,14], Chen et al. [15], Solymosi et al. [1619], Wang et al. [20,21],and Liu et al. [22,23].\"\n          [6] \"The improvement in enhancing activity or stability has been obtained by addition with Fe, Co, W, Zr, Ru and Cu [22,2831].\"\n          [7] \"During the past 8 years, the catalyst modification in term of zeolite micropores was extensively studied [23,3237].\"\n          [8] \"The indirect processes rely upon the production of synthesis gas, either by reforming reaction or by partial oxidation, followed by FischerTropsch chemistry.\"\n          [9] \"For the latter transformation route, methane can be converted to the desired products, e.g. ethylene, methanol, formaldehyde, and aromatics, directly.\"\n          [10] \"The oxidative coupling of methane as an alternative route for the direct conversion of methane had been extensively studied since 1982.\"\n          [11] \"Mitchell and Wanyhorne [8] reported that methane could be activated over M/MOn/MO multi-component catalyst at 977 K to form benzene and/or the carbonaceous deposit.\"\n          [12] \"Belgued et al. [9] demonstrated that methane could be transformed into higher hydrocarbons over a supported Pt catalyst via a two-step route.\"\n          [13] \"Bragin et al. [10] found the aromatization reaction of methane to benzene over PtCrO3/HZSM-5 catalyst at 1023 K in a pulse-reactor.\"\n          [14] \"In 1993, Wang et al. [11] reported that methane could be transformed to benzene in a flow mode reactor on transition metal ions supported HZSM-5 catalysts under non-oxidative condition.\"\n          [15] \"Weckhuysen et al. [26] studied the effect of transition metal ions, the preparation and treatment method.\"\n          [16] \"They found that the activity is in the following sequence: Mo > W > Fe > V > Cr.\"\n          [17] \"Later, Zeng et al. [27] reported the WH2SO4/HZSM-5 was a good catalyst for methane aromatization at 1123 K, however,the formation of coke was neglected.\"\n          [18] \"On the other hand, it should be noted that the addition of a sec- ond metal component is also studied as shown in [12].\"\n          [19] \"The splitting of CH bond is likely from the interaction between CH4 and the surface oxygen species [5].\"\n          [20] \"The direct transformation route for the formation of methanol and formaldehyde [24].\"\n          [21] \"Zeng et al. [27] reported the WH2SO4/HZSM-5 was a good catalyst for methane aromatization at 1123 K, however,the formation of coke was neglected.\"\n          [22] \"Zhang et al. studied the methane aromatization over Mo-based catalysts supported on different types of zeolites [32].\"", "English": "The catalytic dehydrocondensation of methane to benzene and naphthalene on transition metal supported zeolite catalysts is a strategy for the catalytic conversion of methane. The investigation of carbonaceous deposits, the synergetic effect between the transition metal components and the zeolite supports, the active species and reaction mechanisms are revealed by various studies. Many processes related to methane conversion require the use of oxygen, leading to the deep oxidation of methane. Researchers have tried to transform methane into higher hydrocarbons in the absence of oxygen to suppress the formation of undesirable products. Mo/HZSM-5 is generally accepted as a good catalyst for this process. The addition of Fe, Co, W, Zr, Ru and Cu can enhance the activity or stability of the catalyst. The catalyst modification in terms of zeolite micropores has been extensively studied. The indirect processes for methane conversion rely upon the production of synthesis gas, followed by Fischer-Tropsch chemistry. Methane can be directly converted to desired products such as ethylene, methanol, formaldehyde, and aromatics. The oxidative coupling of methane as an alternative route for direct conversion has been extensively studied since 1982. Methane can be activated over multi-component catalysts to form benzene and carbonaceous deposits. Methane can be transformed into higher hydrocarbons over supported Pt catalysts via a two-step route. Methane aromatization to benzene has been achieved over PtCrO3/HZSM-5 catalysts. Methane can be transformed to benzene in a flow mode reactor on transition metal ions supported HZSM-5 catalysts under non-oxidative conditions. The effect of transition metal ions, preparation, and treatment methods on catalysts has been studied. The activity of transition metal ions for methane aromatization follows the sequence: Mo > W > Fe > V > Cr. WH2SO4/HZSM-5 is a good catalyst for methane aromatization at high temperatures, but the formation of coke was neglected. The addition of a second metal component has been studied to enhance activity or stability. The splitting of the CH bond in methane is likely due to the interaction between CH4 and the surface oxygen species. The direct transformation route for the formation of methanol and formaldehyde has been explored. Methane aromatization over Mo-based catalysts supported on different types of zeolites has been investigated.", "Chinese": "甲烷催化脱氢缩合至苯和萘在过渡金属支撑的沸石催化剂上是甲烷催化转化的一种策略。碳沉积物的调查，过渡金属组分与沸石载体之间的协同效应，活性物种和反应机理通过各种研究揭示。许多与甲烷转化相关的工艺需要使用氧气，导致甲烷的深度氧化。为了抑制不期望产物的生成，研究人员尝试在无氧条件下将甲烷转化为更高级的烃类。Mo/HZSM-5通常被认为是一种良好的催化剂。添加Fe、Co、W、Zr、Ru和Cu可以增强催化剂的活性或稳定性。在过去的8年里，沸石微孔的催化剂改性得到了广泛的研究。甲烷转化的间接过程依赖于合成气的生产，随后是费托化学。甲烷可以直接转化为乙烯、甲醇、甲醛和芳烃等所需产品。自1982年以来，甲烷的氧化偶联作为直接转化的替代途径得到了广泛的研究。甲烷可以在多组分催化剂上被激活，形成苯和碳沉积物。甲烷可以通过支撑的Pt催化剂通过两步路线转化为更高碳的烃类。甲烷在PtCrO3/HZSM-5催化剂上可以被芳构化为苯。甲烷可以在非氧化条件下，在过渡金属离子支撑的HZSM-5催化剂的流动模式反应器中转化为苯。已经研究了过渡金属离子、制备和处理方法对催化剂的影响。过渡金属离子对甲烷芳构化的活性顺序为：Mo > W > Fe > V > Cr。WH2SO4/HZSM-5是高温下甲烷芳构化的良好催化剂，但忽视了焦炭的形成。添加第二种金属组分已被研究以增强活性或稳定性。甲烷中CH键的裂解可能由于CH4和表面氧物种之间的相互作用。直接转化路线用于形成甲醇和甲醛。已经研究了不同类型的沸石上Mo基催化剂的甲烷芳构化。", "Doi": "10.1016/s0920-5861(01)00440-0"},
{"Quotes": "\"[1] Supported vanadium oxides have been widely used as catalysts for a number of reactions. The molecular structure of the surface vanadium oxide species and the catalytic properties are influenced by the method of preparation, the nature of support, promotors and environmental conditions [1].\"\n          \"[2] Depending on the vanadium loadings, different vanadium oxide species (V5+) were formed on the surface of alumina after calcination. Mainly isolated and polymerized VO4 units were observed at coverages up to a monolayer [1,5,13] while VO6 octahedra were predominant on catalyst surfaces at higher vanadium loadings [1].\"\n          \"[3] The oxidative dehydrogenation of propane is a strong exothermic reaction and maximum temperatures of about 873 K or higher were observed in the catalytic bed using a more concentrated feed [26].\"\n          \"[4] The objective of the present work is, for that rea- son, the study of the nature and properties of the vanadium oxide species formed on the alumina support calcined at high temperature of 873 K at relatively high vanadium load- ings between 4.5 and 13.2 wt.% vanadium.\"\n          \"[5] The results of characterization will be compared with the catalytic performance in the oxidative dehydrogenation of propane in order to get information about relations between phase composition, coordination,reducibility and dispersion of the vanadium species formed at high vanadium loading.\"\n          \"[6] The highest propene selectivity was obtained for the sample with the highest dispersion of the isolated and polymerized tetrahedrally coordinated V5+ species.\"\n          \"[7] It is suggested that both isolated and polymerized tetrahedrally coordinated V5+ species are active in propane dehydrogenation. The AlVO4 phase and bulk-like V2O5 have only a low catalytic activity.\"\n          \"[8] The portion of vanadium present as AlVO4 increases with increasing vanadium loadings (e.g. about 60 at 13.2 wt.%).\"", "English": "The molecular structure of surface vanadium oxide species and catalytic properties are influenced by preparation method, support nature, promotors, and environmental conditions. Different vanadium oxide species (V5+) form on alumina surfaces depending on vanadium loadings, with isolated and polymerized VO4 units at lower coverages and VO6 octahedra at higher loadings. Propane oxidative dehydrogenation is strongly exothermic, with maximum temperatures around 873 K or higher observed in catalytic beds with concentrated feeds. Studies focus on the nature and properties of vanadium oxide species formed on alumina support at high temperatures and high vanadium loadings, relating phase composition, coordination, reducibility, and dispersion to catalytic performance. The highest propene selectivity is achieved with the highest dispersion of isolated and polymerized tetrahedrally coordinated V5+ species. Both isolated and polymerized tetrahedrally coordinated V5+ species are active in propane dehydrogenation, while the AlVO4 phase and bulk-like V2O5 have low catalytic activity. The portion of vanadium present as AlVO4 increases with increasing vanadium loadings.", "Chinese": "表面钒氧化物的分子结构和催化性能受制备方法、支撑物性质、促进剂和环境条件的影响。根据钒的负载量，不同的V5+钒氧化物物种在氧化铝表面形成，较低覆盖度下主要为孤立和聚合的VO4单元，而较高负载量下主要为VO6八面体。丙烷的氧化脱氢是一个强烈的放热反应，在催化床中使用浓缩进料时，观察到约873 K或更高的最大温度。研究重点是高温和高钒负载条件下，在氧化铝支撑上形成的钒氧化物物种的性质和特性，以及相组成、配位、还原性和分散性与催化性能之间的关系。具有最高分散度的孤立和聚合的四面体配位V5+物种可获得最高的丙烯选择性。孤立和聚合的四面体配位V5+物种在丙烷脱氢中都是活性的，而AlVO4相和类体V2O5只有低催化活性。以AlVO4形式存在的钒的份额随钒负载量的增加而增加。", "Doi": "10.1016/j.apcata.2004.05.050"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions. The introduction of metals such as Ga, Fe, and Zn into HZSM-5 cavities by sublimation results in the formation of various active species, including oxo ions like (GaO)+ and (HOFeOFeOH)2+, which are identified by temperature-programmed reduction with H2 and CO, and in the case of the binuclear Fe3+ ion, by ESR spectroscopy. These species contribute to the acidity of the catalysts, with the ratio of Lewis to Brnsted acid sites increasing in the sequence HZSM-5 < Ga/ZSM-5 < Fe/ZSM-5 < Zn/ZSM-5. The presence of these active species and the resulting acidity are crucial for the efficiency of alkane transformations. The industrial significance of these catalysts is attributed to their ability to catalyze reactions such as the MTG process, the manufacture of olefins from methanol, and the aromatization of light alkanes, which are important in the petrochemical industry. The introduction of metals like Ga, Fe, and Zn into HZSM-5 zeolites by sublimation leads to the formation of strong Lewis acid sites and the regeneration of Brnsted acid sites, which are crucial for catalytic activity. The strength and density of these acid sites, as well as the stability and reducibility of the metal species, play a critical role in the selectivity and conversion of alkanes. The industrial significance of these catalysts is attributed to their ability to catalyze reactions like the MTG process, the manufacture of olefins from methanol, and the aromatization of light alkanes, which are essential for the petrochemical industry. The introduction of metals such as Ga, Fe, and Zn into HZSM-5 cavities by sublimation results in the formation of strong Lewis acid sites and the regeneration of Brnsted acid sites, which are crucial for catalytic activity. The strength and density of these acid sites, as well as the presence of metal ions in various coordination environments, play a critical role in the selectivity and conversion of alkanes. The industrial significance of these catalysts is attributed to their ability to catalyze reactions under mild conditions, reduce energy consumption, and increase product yields, making them economically viable for large-scale production processes. The introduction of metals such as Ga, Fe, and Zn into HZSM-5 zeolites by sublimation results in the formation of strong Lewis acid sites and the regeneration of Brnsted acid sites, which can be stronger or weaker depending on the metal. The presence of these acid sites affects the catalytic activity and selectivity in alkane transformations. The reaction conditions, such as temperature and the presence of reducing or oxidizing atmospheres, can also influence the nature of the active species and thus the catalytic performance. The industrial significance of these catalysts lies in their ability to catalyze reactions such as the MTG process, the manufacture of olefins from methanol, and the aromatization of light alkanes, which are important in the petrochemical industry. The introduction of metals such as Ga, Fe, and Zn into HZSM-5 cavities by sublimation results in the formation of various active species, including binuclear Fe3+ ions, (GaO)+ ions, and Zn2+ cations, which can compensate the charge of two Al-centered tetrahedra or attach themselves to one silanol group or ZnOH and one Al-centered tetrahedron. These species contribute to the acidity of the catalysts, with the ratio of Lewis to Brnsted sites increasing in the sequence HZSM-5 < Ga/ZSM-5 < Fe/ZSM-5 < Zn/ZSM-5. The strength of these Lewis sites also increases in the order Al > Ga > Zn > Fe. The presence of these active species and the resulting acidity are crucial for the efficiency of alkane transformations in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions. The industrial significance of these catalysts is due to their ability to catalyze the conversion of alkanes into more valuable products, such as olefins and aromatics, which are essential in the petrochemical industry.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件，包括支撑的钒氧化物和金属交换沸石，对烷烃转化，特别是在氧化脱氢和沸石催化反应等过程中的机制和效率有重大影响。通过升华将Ga、Fe和Zn等金属引入HZSM-5的空腔中，会形成各种活性物种，包括像(GaO)+和(HOFeOFeOH)2+这样的氧离子，这些物种通过H2和CO的温度程序还原，以及在二核Fe3+离子的情况下，通过ESR光谱学来识别。这些物种对催化剂的酸性有贡献，Lewis酸位与Brnsted酸位的比例按HZSM-5 < Ga/ZSM-5 < Fe/ZSM-5 < Zn/ZSM-5的顺序增加。这些活性物种的存在和由此产生的酸性对于烷烃转化的效率至关重要。这些催化剂的工业重要性归因于它们能够催化MTG过程、从甲醇制造烯烃和轻烷烃的芳构化等反应，这些反应在石化工业中非常重要。通过升华将Ga、Fe和Zn等金属引入HZSM-5沸石，会形成强Lewis酸位点，并再生Brnsted酸位点，这对催化活性至关重要。这些酸位点的强度和密度，以及金属物种的稳定性和还原性，在选择性和烷烃转化中起着关键作用。这些催化剂的工业重要性在于它们能够催化MTG过程、从甲醇制造烯烃和轻烷烃的芳构化等反应，这些反应对石化工业至关重要。通过升华将Ga、Fe和Zn等金属引入HZSM-5的空腔中，会形成强Lewis酸位点，并再生Brnsted酸位点，这对催化活性至关重要。这些酸位点的强度和密度，以及金属离子在不同配位环境中的存在，对烷烃的选择性和转化起着关键作用。这些催化剂的工业重要性在于它们能够在温和条件下催化反应，减少能耗，提高产品产量，使其在大规模生产过程中具有经济可行性。通过升华将Ga、Fe和Zn等金属引入HZSM-5沸石中，会形成强Lewis酸位点，并再生Brnsted酸位点，这些酸位点的强度取决于金属的种类。这些酸位点的存在影响了烷烃转化的催化活性和选择性。反应条件，如温度和还原或氧化气氛的存在，也会影响活性物种的性质，从而影响催化性能。这些催化剂的工业重要性在于它们能够催化MTG过程、从甲醇制造烯烃和轻烷烃的芳构化等反应，这些反应在石油化工行业中至关重要。通过升华将Ga、Fe和Zn等金属引入HZSM-5的空腔中，会形成各种活性物种，包括二核Fe3+离子、(GaO)+离子和Zn2+阳离子，这些阳离子可以补偿两个Al中心四面体的电荷，或者附着在一个硅醇基团或ZnOH和一个Al中心四面体上。这些物种对催化剂的酸性有贡献，Lewis与Brnsted位点的比例按HZSM-5 < Ga/ZSM-5 < Fe/ZSM-5 < Zn/ZSM-5的顺序增加。这些Lewis位点的强度也按Al > Ga > Zn > Fe的顺序增加。这些活性物种的存在和由此产生的酸性对于氧化脱氢和沸石催化反应等过程中烷烃转化的效率至关重要。这些催化剂的工业重要性在于它们能够催化烷烃转化为更有价值的产品，如烯烃和芳烃，这些产品在石化工业中是必不可少的。", "Doi": "10.1021/jp990116l"},

this reaction, and by avoiding the presence of water,isolated oxo species of molybdenum in oxidation state VI were obtained with a large dispersion.\"\n          [22] \"On account of the specific activity of these iso- lated MoO42species, the new grafted Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst greatly improves the formaldehyde yield in the methane partial oxidation reaction with re- spect to those of the classical impregnated W and Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts.\"", "English": "The composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, significantly influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions. A new methane partial oxidation (MPO) catalyst was prepared by grafting MoO2(acac)2 onto the surface of dried HZSM-5 zeolite. After the grafting reaction, the solid was washed, dried, and calcined in air to afford the final [S]O2MoO2, Mo(VI), highly dispersed, surface species. The catalytic activity of this new material in the MPO reaction is enhanced in comparison with the classical Mo,W/HZSM-5 impregnation catalysts. The conversion of methane into organic compounds of greater interest is of significant scientific and industrial relevance due to the large natural gas reserves, of which methane is the principal component. Transformation of methane into methanol or formaldehyde is a very attractive process since the former compound can be converted into liquid fuels similar to gasoline, and the latter is a key component in a number of synthetic organic methods. The weakness of the CH bond of methane, caused by distortion of the methane molecule through its interaction with the zeolite surface, has been proposed as the first step in the methane activation mechanism. Formaldehyde selectivity was dependent on the dispersion and the nature of the metal oxide supported phase. Grafting of transition metal complexes onto reactive surface structures is an expeditious alternative method to obtain catalytic systems with definable structure and composition, offering potential for the design of efficient catalysts with an advantageous combination of specific properties of both homogeneous and heterogeneous systems. The UV diffuse reflectance spectra of the samples exhibit absorption bands near 240 nm due to ligand-to-metal charge transfer transitions, in accordance with the presence of the proposed MoO42molybdenum(VI) species on the surface. XPS analysis indicates the presence of highly dispersed molybdenum(VI) species. The XRD spectra of the catalysts were registered and compared to those of the pure support, MoO2(acac)2, and MoO3, showing that the reaction between the complex and the surface OH groups allows us to obtain highly dispersed oxo species. In the case of aqueous impregnation, aggregates of MoO3 are usually detected. The relatively high values of CO selectivity for the two Mo/HZSM-5 catalysts can be attributed to the presence of residual acid sites on the zeolite surface. The high degree of surface covering in the W/HZSM-5 catalyst leads to a lower CO selectivity. A new catalyst for the MPO reaction was obtained by grafting MoO2(acac)2 onto the surface of the HZSM-5 zeolite, resulting in isolated oxo species of molybdenum in oxidation state VI with a large dispersion. The specific activity of these isolated MoO42species greatly improves the formaldehyde yield in the methane partial oxidation reaction.", "Chinese": "金属基催化剂的组成、结构和反应条件，包括支撑的钒氧化物和金属交换沸石，对烷烃转化，特别是氧化脱氢和沸石催化反应的机制和效率有重大影响。一种新的甲烷部分氧化(MPO)催化剂是通过将MoO2(acac)2嫁接到干燥的HZSM-5沸石表面制备的。嫁接反应后，固体被洗涤、干燥，并在空气中煅烧，以获得最终的[S]O2MoO2，Mo(VI)，高度分散的表面物种。这种新材料在MPO反应中的催化活性与传统的Mo,W/HZSM-5浸渍催化剂相比有所增强。将甲烷转化为更感兴趣的有机化合物在科学和工业上具有重要意义，这是由于大量的天然气储备，其中甲烷是主要成分。将甲烷转化为甲醇或甲醛是一个非常有吸引力的过程，因为前者化合物可以转化为类似于汽油的液体燃料，而后者是许多合成有机方法的关键成分。甲烷分子与沸石表面的相互作用导致的甲烷分子的扭曲，被提议为甲烷活化机制的第一步。甲醛的选择性取决于金属氧化物支撑相的分散度和性质。将过渡金属配合物嫁接到反应性表面结构上是一种有效的替代方法，可以得到具有可定义结构和组成的催化系统，从工业角度来看，这种方法为设计具有均相和异相系统特定属性有利组合的高效催化剂提供了潜力。样品的紫外漫反射光谱在约240纳米处显示出吸收带，这是由于配体到金属电荷转移跃迁，与表面提出的MoO42钼(VI)物种的存在一致。XPS分析表明存在高度分散的钼(VI)物种。催化剂的XRD光谱被记录下来，并与纯支撑物、MoO2(acac)2和MoO3的光谱进行了比较，显示复合物与表面OH基团之间的反应使我们能够得到高度分散的氧化物种。在水性浸渍的情况下，通常会检测到MoO3的聚集体。两个Mo/HZSM-5催化剂的CO选择性的相对较高值可归因于沸石表面残留的酸性位点。W/HZSM-5催化剂的高表面覆盖度导致较低的CO选择性。一种新的MPO反应催化剂是通过将MoO2(acac)2嫁接到HZSM-5沸石表面获得的，结果得到了氧化态VI的钼的孤立氧化物种，具有很大的分散度。这些孤立的MoO42物种的特定活性大大提高了甲烷部分氧化反应中甲醛的产量。", "Doi": "10.1016/s0926-860x(99)00423-8"},
{"Quotes": "", "English": "The literature does not provide specific information on how the composition, structure, and reaction conditions of metal-based catalysts, including supported vanadium oxides and metal-exchanged zeolites, influence the mechanisms and efficiency of alkane transformations, particularly in processes such as oxidative dehydrogenation and zeolite-catalyzed reactions, and what factors contribute to their industrial significance. However, it does discuss the quantum chemical study of mechanisms for oxidative dehydrogenation of propane on vanadium oxide, which is of great interest in industrial catalysis. The study found that the potential energy surface has large barriers, which are lowered somewhat when the possibility of a triplet state is considered. The barriers on the reaction pathway are 45-80 kcal/mol above the energy of the reactants, which are much larger than found experimentally for propane ODH on supported vanadia. Some of the barriers may be reduced by consideration of more complex reactions, such as a concerted reaction involving adsorption of O2 during water elimination. The reduction of other barriers, such as for propane adsorption, appears to require the involvement of a support for the vanadium oxide catalyst.", "Chinese": "文献没有提供具体信息，说明金属基催化剂（包括支撑的钒氧化物和金属交换沸石）的组成、结构和反应条件如何影响烷烃转化的机制和效率，特别是在氧化脱氢和沸石催化反应等过程中，以及哪些因素对它们的工业意义有贡献。但是，它确实讨论了关于钒氧化物上丙烷氧化脱氢机制的量子化学研究，这在工业催化中具有极大的兴趣。研究发现，势能面有大的能垒，当考虑三重态的可能性时，能垒会降低一些。反应途径上的能垒比反应物的能量高45-80 kcal/mol，这比实验中在支撑的钒酸盐上发现的丙烷ODH大得多。一些能垒可以通过考虑更复杂的反应来降低，例如在水消除过程中涉及O2吸附的协同反应。降低其他能垒，如丙烷吸附，似乎需要催化剂的支撑参与。", "Doi": "10.1021/jp056228w"},
{"Quotes": "[1] \"The conversion of light alkanes to more useful products. The catalytic conversion of methane in particular to methanol [ 1, 21 or higher hydrocarbons [ 3-51 has received much attention.\"\n          [2] \"In con- trast, the conversion of higher alkanes, such as C&/C, cuts, can proceed in the absence of such co-reactants.\"\n          [3] \"Catalytic dehydrogenation of propane and butane to alkenes is at the heart of processes such as Oleflex [ 71, Aromatization processes such as Cyclar [ 8, 91 and MB-forming [lo] have also recently been announced.\"\n          [4] \"These processes of- fer a means of converting light gases to aromatics, especially BTX,and are based on the use of catalysts such as ZSM-5 and related materials.\"\n          [5] \"The conversion of light alkanes such as propane and butane to aromatics is not completely selective. Higher alkanes, such as C&/C, can be converted without co-reactants.
